text: We stayed for Christmas 2007 and agree with other reviewers that the hotel has been beautifully refurbished. We had a fantastic room with a sea view, very comfy bed, huge bathroom, all spotlessly clean. The pool area is stunning and the pool attendants very helpful in brining loungers, towels and refreshing slices of watermelon. A few rupees on day one will get you a great spot and a parasol for the rest of your stay! However we were disappointed with both the food and the service. Yes the fine dinning is superb but overall the food was too "international" with very limited choice for those of us that travel in Asia for the delicious local food. As there is absolutely nothing outside of the hotel ,and only very limited choices if you take long a taxi ride to other towns along the coast, we soon became bored with the choice of one Sri lanka curry, one chinese style stir fry and the local dish of Devilled chicken. Personally we don't travel for 11 hours to eat a rack of lamb no matter how good it is! The hotel was busy at it was Chistmas and it took ages to get served, particularly at the pool bar. Over one hour for a sandwich and a beer for lunch on one occaision. Overal the hotel is excellent provided you like an "all inclusive" type of holiday. Having travelled extensivley in India, Thailand, and Malaysia we were a little disappointed in Sri Lanka overall. It takes forever to get anywhere as the roads are so bad and so congested, the food wasn't that great anywhere, Columbo is polluted and rather grim. Whilst the beaches in the South are fantastic we enjoyed our stay further North more. Tragically there is still a long way to go to recover from the Tsunami. The lack of tourists is having the effect that those that do go are seen as "cash cows" we felt somewhat ripped off on more than one occaision. Beware the moonstone mines - you can buy them cheaper in the UK!

text: After a week of touring around Sri Lanka for the first part of our honeymoon we were looking forward to spending a week by the sea in a 5 star resort. Unfotunately we were very disappointed with this hotel. The good points about the hotel are the large swimming pools and the view of the sea from most parts of the hotel. The bad points are numerous: -During our stay the weather was very windy and it rained heavily. The hotel is not designed to cope heavy rainfall as it is designed in a very modern, open minimalist way. All the corridors, a bar and the cafe are completely open to the elements. This meant that rain was constantly pouring in and the floors were several centimetres deep in some places. This made the floors very slippy and we found we were unable to get around the hotel much and it made sitting in the front bar and cafe impossible as the bar does not have any front covers to keep the rain out. The staff are constantly sweeping the water away and moving furniture around out of the rain which was very irritating. The overall cleanliness of the hotel is not that great either and the hotel is starting to look rundown. The bathroom in our room had lots of mould in the shower(picture attached), and there was no bath option, you have to pay for a premium top floor room to get a bath! Having stayed in many 5 star and 4 star hotels all over Europe and Asia, I would say this is a 3 star at best, the other 3 star hotels we stayed in during our holiday were in fact much better. -The food is boring and pricey by Sri Lankan standards although you would expect that in a 5 star hotel. We went to the fine dining restaurant one night which was pretty good, although very run-of-the-mill options such as steak and mash. The desserts were interesting but after waiting over half an hour, when they arrived they were poorly executed and my dessert was not even what I ordered. Being the only other couple in the restaurant this was certainly not what we expected. The breakfast is also disappointing, the only positive being the traditional Sri Lankan curries offered. The omelette queue was impressive every morning and that only left under-cooked waffles, anaemic chicken sausages and fatty bacon cooked to order. The rest of the buffet was luke-warm at best. The fresh fruit offered however was fesh and ripe and there was lots of choice. -The beach is not for swimming or being on for any length of time. There are local people constantly waiting on the edge of the hotel and the beach trying to sell you things aggressively and stray dogs wandering about do not make you feel safe. The security guards do nothing about the sellers and leave them to shout at you whilst you are lying on sunbeds within the hotel grounds. -Another point to make is that there is nothing to do in the local area- we went to the 'turtle hatchery' before going to the hotel and it took us 10min to look at the 2 ponds in which 2 poor adult turtles are kept, and a small area of sand where the eggs are buried before they hatch. We ended up leaving early as we were fed up with the food, not being able to go on to the beach and the inefficient staff. Wish we had gone to the Maldives!

text: Our stay here cost about Â£180 per night for a double room. Overall the hotel is nice but just not really living up to the standards you'd expect of a 4 star hotel or the price tag. For example the toilets in the reception area were rather dark and needed a clean and tidy, there were lots of staff around but so many of them doing nothing and at one time I had to ask 5 different staff to order drinks over a period of about 20 mins before anything actually happened, a lot of the time the waiting staff seemed to just cluster in groups and were lost if actually asked to do anything. The cushions on the sun loungers were ancient, one of the things we noticed that should be easy to put right if the hotel put some of its profits back into the premises. The hotel makes a lot of its 'award winning' chefs which became a bit irritating after a couple of days as some food was great, some really not so good and I had the only stomach upset of the entire trip after eating at the hotel as did a couple of the family, I think due to food being reheated as some things looked rather familiar. Also they seemed thrown at breakfast if more than one or two people wanted the freshly cooked items such as hoppers so you had to wait absolutely ages or give up and have items that were not needing cooking - a real shame as I love my Dosa and hoppers! The kids club was good but the evening entertainment seemed to be the male ents team dressing in drag every night and miming to something and they seemed to abandon the kids pretty quickly if there was any sign of mingling with the grown ups. The other big downer for the hotel is the mosquitoes which are absolutely rife, not totally avoidable but I feel they could have made more of an effort with the rooms and common areas to minimise the mozzy numbers - as most of the other hotels we stayed in had done. Plus points were the two nice pools and the nice view of the sea. Without a fantastic rate to entice me back I'd be inclined to try somewhere else along the coast when I next go back.

text: We have just returned from a fabulous 2 week honeymoon in Sri Lanka. We had stayed in 3 fab places before our final stop at The Heritance. From looking at the website and booking the holiday through a luxury travel agent, it looked like it was going to be a lovely retreat to relax in for 5 days. Unfortunately this wasnâ€™t quite the case... I had e-mailed and Facebook messaged the hotel the day before arrival. I asked whether they had any suites or some of their best rooms available to upgrade to, as we were on our honeymoon and wished for something extra special. The responded via Facebook asking for my e-mail address so that they could forward information on. I responded and I didnâ€™t get anything back. I then e-mailed them directly-nothing back again!! Nothing was said on check in...no special greeting...nothing. We were taken to our room, I told the lady taking us there that I had e-mailed and wanted to make sure we got a sea view. She was quite dismissive. When we got to our room, it was ground floor level taking us straight out to the pool. You could hear the sea, but defiantly couldnâ€™t see it. The room was pleasant enough-modern with a big bed but definatly not 5 star. There was a congratulations cake on the table to great us (we had one at most places we stayed to be honest). But that was the only thing we got to feel special. No one asked whether we would like to organise a special dinner etc etc. As the cake was so big, it was going to take us several days to eat it. Housekeeping could have taken it away and put it in the fridge, but instead it was left out on the side to attract ants. We were just overall a bit disappointed...it was defiantly more of a family hotel and there were kids everywhere the whole weekend we were there and breakfast was crazy-we thought that the hotel was opening up the restaurant and pool to non residents at the weekend. The restaurant needs a facelift for sure as it again did not feel like 5* dining. At breakfast we always waited patiently to be seated, once seated the waitress or waiter would hurry off without asking whether we would like tea or coffee. I then had to try and grab someoneâ€™s attention again so it basically took 15 minutes to get a hot drink. A little poor for 5*. We had lunch via room service a couple of days and that was pleasant enough-very little choice but if you like chips and sandwiches then itâ€™s fine. They had no samosas and very few of the wines on the extensive wine list on show. I had to chose 3 different wines before finally getting the 4th one I asked for. Also if you like cocktails, you will be disappointed as the ones I had at the hotel were not very nice. We only ate dinner in the restaurant once during our 5 night stop, as we decided we would get better service and food elsewhere. The fine dining restaurant had no people in on any of the nights we were there and we just couldnâ€™t think of anything worse than the madness of that buffet restaurant again. Where the staff were in attentive and miserable. Sorry Heritance but we just expected more Iâ€™m sorry. And to top it all off we got a phone call the morning of check-out just to make sure we were checking out on time or if we had booked a late check out. And a bill pushed through the door the night before. Come on...it was low season, hotel was not busy at all and we were on our honeymoon. Every morning we were woken at 5am by noisy people checking out of their rooms or walking in high heels right above our bedroom. With being on the ground floor, we were right on the main drag for people moving around. If we had been higher up with a lovely sea view, then we would have hopefully had some peace and quiet.

text: Just got back from the Heritance and had a marvellous time there.It is beautifully designed,with two infinity pools leading your eye out to the sea.Our room had a great sea view and was very well furnished.Beds were comfy and the bathroom was great-I want a wet room like theirs!!!Premiership matches on the box and two english speaking movie channels. The food was very good and i found myself eating curry three times a day!!i also brought a hopper pan back with me to have egg-hoppers for beakfast.However we were a little disappointed with the fine dining restaurant.The prices are the same as back home, and they had very pretty food on the plate, but it needs Gordon Ramsey to go in and make it less fussy and more tasty.With such good seafood(the tuna is the best!) i would have liked to have seen a japanese restaurant or something similar.The 'mustard' coffe shop was more to our liking-less pretentious and good food,and of course you can always find something nice in the buffet restaurant. Service is very good,if a little too much! Sri Lanka is a paradise for wildlife and the hotel has in it's grounds; egrets,bee-eaters,squirrels,a small monitor lizard,gecko's and on an evening a large bat which we named 'Nora' (Batty!) which swooped around the pool bar while we were sipping pre dinner Martini's! We went on a river cruise through the mangroves which was excellent and a trip to Sinharaja Rainforest ,which is a must for bird watchers.Our driver Erish was the best.He took us around the village he grew up in and to meet some of his family,and releasing baby turtles into the sea at Kosgoda was very satisfying. Don't let tales of war in the north put you off going,you are not affected in the least.Soldiers with guns are at a lot of check points near Colombo,but there are thousands of Tamils and Sinhalese living in perfect harmony,it is lot more safe than Northern Ireland ever was.Just keep away from the north and north east to be on the safe side. They have recovered physically very well from the Tsunami,but anyone you talk to has lost loved ones(60,000 people)There won't be another one for hundreds of years,so don't let that put you off either! The Hotel is excellent and Sri Lanka is a lush,wildlife filled paradise,with sun and picture postcard beaches.It reminded me of a cross between Thailand(with Buddhist temples all over) and the nicer parts of south goa,give it a try.We'll definitely go back.

I've seen better verity in average buffets. Try a different hotel before considering this.

text: Booked over the phone for 3 nights which was ok enough. Nice enough hotel with a decent location though the beach was not as nice as you'd get in the east coast or even some Other parts of west coast of Sri Lanka. Most of our time was spent in the 2 pools as were the others from what it seemed as the sea was too rough during our stay. Food was ok, mainly buffet type of food with a decent variety though the fruit selection seems to be the same everyday (melon, papaya, pineapple & guava) Rooms and the hotel was a little dated to be honest and not worthy of 5 or even 4 star, especially compared to some of the other hotels we've stayed during this trip to SL. I do admit though that I have high expectations usually and wouldn't mind paying for it but this hotel was rather less expensive compared to the others and kind of explains why you get dated room & decor (get what you pay for right??) One things I should mention however was the price of food and drinks. It is an absolute rip off when looking at the cost of drinks. All the menu prices are expensive enough , but they add a mandatory service charge of 10% and government VAT 12.5% on top of the final bill which make you pay about 800 LKR (about Â£4) for a bottle of Corona. Note that local beverages are not cheaper either. A small bottle of water is about 225 LKR which is little too expensive compared to other Sri Lankan luxury hotels. The location itself is not close to Galle so not much to do outside of the hotel. We did do a boat trip on Madu river (about 10 miles out) which was as well worth it but I'd suggest you don't book through the hotel and go directly to the Balapitiya bride where you can see many tour operators and get a boat for a ride. Takes about 90 mins and cost us 2000 LKR (Â£10) which was well worth it. There also is a turtle hatchery that you can visit which is nice. I probably wouldn't come back to this hotel to be honest as I wasn't overly impressed but could be a decent location for the average, budget conscious traveller looking for a bargain, as long as the price remain cheap.

text: Property : Beautiful architecture, bright outdoor spaces and two amazing swimming pools and a useless beach. Rooms: Needs an upgrade to the really bad lighting system. Rooms are very dark and not at all child friendly. Beds are comfy n pillows are great. Room cleanliness is not all satisfied. Cigarette hash underneath the bed looks as if it had not been cleaned for ages. Food: The Salads are not at all up to the standard. Soup was a good start. Main course buffet was a bit messed up. Potatoes burnt while the cuttle fish left raw n the crabs too sweet n also uncooked for dinner. Lunch was way better. The positive point is that the staff after informing made us an ala carte dish of crabs and prawns and it was amazing. Desert was spot on delicious. Variety was also another plus point. Staff: The happy smiling faces and welcoming gestures by the overall staff make you want to come back again to this property. Thanks to Mr Thushara the Food manager and the head Chef and also all the other staff for making our stay a pleasant one. We look forward to coming back to heritance Ahungalla with a better expectation. Imran Hinghora

text: The hotel was right on the beach, gated and setback from the main street.with numerous restaurants to choose from. We found the coffee shop lobster more superior to the fine dining restaurant experience. Great buffet breakfast-try the hoppers. The gym was the only disappointment with 2 walking machines and one permanently broken. Pools were great but ocean too wild to swim due to monsoon rains that came and went. The spa was average-reasonable prices but service disappointing. We went to the turtle farm nearby and other day trips are possible. text: My fiancÃ© and I returned to this hotel following a stay in 2011. We enjoyed our time spent here and combined a visit to Ella and a stay in a guest house in Kosgoda. We would agree with other reviews that the hotel is in need of updating, however we heard that they are closing the hotel next year for improvements. Having said that, the rooms are fine and all areas are very clean (just quite tired). The service and hospitality is very good and friendly, the bar staff, pool/sunbed staff and especially the lovely man we had cleaning the room (Asoka), we saw him every day and he always went over and above, asking if there was anything he can do or anyway he could improve our room. We actually asked to change rooms as we weren't happy with the view from our first balcony (it overlooked the pool and we wanted something a little more private) and within 30 minutes a new room that suited us was ready. The pool area and garden are beautifully maintained and we loved our time spent around the pool overlooking beautiful Ahungalla beach. We stayed on a B&B basis as we enjoy eating outside of the hotel and there are lovely places to do this; the two beach restaurants just a 5 minute walk from the hotel (jungle restaurant and sunshine restaurant), a beautiful restaurant in the next town along (sankarest garden restaurant, a 5 minute tuk tuk ride at 250 rps). There are also other restaurants in Bentota but this is slightly further afield, 20 minute tuk tuk journey at c. 700 rps (depending on how you haggle). We went to tutle hatchery whilst there and a boat trip, both very worthwhile doing. As previously said, the beach is beautiful and very quiet however, I would be interested to see how it changes once the 500 room (vs. heritance 140) hotel next door is completed in two years time. As other reviews have said, you do get a bit of hassle from the beach sellers however this didn't bother us to much and seemed to die down after a couple of days of saying 'no'. We did book a boat trip through a nice guy called Charli who we'd met and had trips with in 2011, you can find him on the beach and ask any of the sellers for him as they all know each other. We would have liked to have taken the opportunity to hire bikes from the hotel but the weather was just to hot during our stay for either of us to have wanted to do this! Overall we really enjoyed our stay at heritance.

text: Excellent location and beach. Hotel is a fantastic design. Great food and the majority of the staff are really friendly. Unfortunately however, although the management have repeated on a number of occasions that the renovations have been completed, they are far from complete. We did have a look at some of the rooms that had been renovated and they looked excellent. Unfortunately, we weren't in one of these, our room was extremely dated, the cleaning was not done to a very high standard and we don't think the balcony had ever been cleaned! We used the pool furthest from reception which was excellent, with well-kept lawns. The major problem here is that there are only 8 umbrellas, unless you want to sit under the trees, we we didn't. I always sit under an umbrella and my wife always sits in the the sun but the problem is that the pool boy reserves the beds/umbrella's for those that have tipped him previously which then involved us having to have an argument with him most mornings to get a place with an umbrella - on some days there were 2 or 3 umbrella's/sun chairs that he had reserved but there weren't used all day as the guests must have gone out for the day, but he wouldn't let anyone sit on them! The main pool at reception area is excellent although the surrounding lawn areas are extremely scruffy. Overall had an enjoyable holiday and stay at this hotel but the room we stayed in wasn't up to standard. Stayed first 2 weeks in Feb 2017.

If you are looking for a beach side paradise with a modern room with quiet aircon and sliding doors onto a pool that is pure bliss for midnight swims then this cant be faulted. Food is great, plenty of options and places to eat, your room, the terrace, cafe or fine dining. Tennis, Snooker and yoga, not in that order.... We stayed in 5 hotels from Kandy, Nuwara, Dambulla and here. this was the best value and the most excellent. service was fab. Although all heritance hotels are good the one at Dambulla is triple the price for example; for food and beverages. Stay at the earls regeency or mahawali reach in kandy> tea plantation or St andrews in Nuwara Elya and the kandalama in Dambulla, expensive but a truely natural experience, like having a safari in your room! monkeys on the balcony, bats in the corridors and an infinty pool overlooking the wilderness. Snakes and lizards every where, in a nice way! oh and if you want golf the only place to play is the sublime course near Kandy at victoria. a real gem. Enjoy

text: Pros - great view of the ocean (sea view avaiable with Premium rooms0 - speacious clean rooms - good size pools (note there are two pools, and one is mostly only offered to foreigners) - good spread for buffet (but its almost the same everyday for bfast) Cons - teriible reception/front desk service; had a don't care attitude and were often rude - had electrical problems in the room when the fan was turned on but even after informing the reception twice (on two seperate days), they did nothing about it..did not even apologise or offer to change the room - requested king/queen bed but were only given twin mattresses - no bath tubs, this is only available in luxury rooms - Not much choice for in-room dining - Don't visit during the weekends; the hotel allows far too many groups to have the spend the day on the weekends (allowing one or two groups is fine but there should be a limit so that the pools are not over crowded); My personal opinion is that the hotel treated foreigners differently to the locals (including locals from overseas); with the locals, they just didn't care. Me and my husband are Sri Lankans and we visit Sri Lanka often and like to escape out of colombo for a few days. We were really disappointed with the way they treated us. I think i've had far better service in other hotels in the area (bentota etc). Great hotel but would not recommend due to the horrible service.

text: I had the Heritance recommended from someone I know...clearly we have different taste or it was a different Heritance they stayed at. We booked this place for our last night in Sri Lanka as closer to Colombo and also looked lovely from the website. We so wished we had stayed at our gorgeous little boutique hotel in Mirissa instead! I won't make that mistake again...this is definitely a nice enough place for families or people looking for an all-in-one, resort experience, the beach is very pretty and so are the pools and lounge area with lots of grass and trees. Our room was OK but as many people say, 'tired' and not the cleanest ever, although a very good shower. The food, a buffet, was decent, but definitely nowhere near the food we had during our entire stay in Sri Lanka at a fraction of the cost. We had a hefty service charge added to our bill simply for ordering 1 bottle of wine at dinner! We booked a massage at the spa there which was good, and took advantage of the tennis courts. There are certainly plenty of facilities, but the various sales-people around selling tourist goods and palm readings made it that little bit more resorty/touristy for us. Overall, definitely not for the traveller who likes to stay less 'chainy' hotels (I was also enticed by their 'eco' claims but not sure I saw much to support it?) and I would not call it 5 star, but I probably made a mistake in booking it in the first place for what we wanted!

text: We stayed at the Heritance Ahungalla for our honeymoon and were not disappointed. Having done our research we liked the more traditional style, location and hotel size from looking at reviews on TripAdvisor. This is a beautiful hotel, very clean with some fantastic staff. I did unfortunately injure myself while we were there but the staff were very caring and attentive. The food was very good and there was a good variety although it was unusual that not all the restaurants were included as part of the all-inclusive and wine only available at meal times. Our room was beautiful and we had a stunning view of the beach which was right on our doorstep. The only piece of criticism I would have, would be that the walkways and grounds could do with a little more manicuring between the two pools as this looked a bit untidy. All in all we had an amazing stay and I would recommend this hotel. Sri Lanka as a country is beautiful with an abundance of exotic wildlife, culture and some of the friendliest people you will ever meet. This was certainly a memorable destination for our honeymoon, different from anywhere I have ever been and we would love to go back and explore more.

text: This is a great hotel in many ways. It is a Bawa design so the actual structure and lay out of the resort is outstanding. The rooms are well appointed with great showers. But for the price and the history of the place I thought the resort could have been better. 1) The resort falls down in comparison to other world class hotels in the details. For example, every room is given a fruit basket designed to resemble a traditional Sri Lankan out rigger. This is a great touch but the problem is that the boat basket was quite broken and falling apart. It should have been replaced long ago. There are examples of this where a good idea is not quite executed correctly. Another example was the intrusion of more conventional resorts into the appearance of this heritage building: in the bar area upstairs there was a Red Bull fridge displayed quite prominently. Does anyone truly think Bawa would have approved of such a thing? Of course not. It disrupts the entire point of a place built by Bawa and damages the aesthetic. The managers should be aware of this. 2) The food was okay but was a mass produced buffet designed to accommodate a large number of people. This led to the food becoming pretty routine after a few days. We also found that it was difficult to get the attention of staff and I found they were not very attentive. Sometimes we had to ask twice for something simple like water. My feeling was that they were very understaffed. 3) A big issue for me was the mattresses. I have some muscular skeletal problems so sleeping on a hard bed is not good for me. But the beds at Ahungalla were very hard. In general I cannot understand why they would not get medium softness beds to accomodate everyone's needs. These may seem like small details, but for the price, for the fact it is a 5 star hotel, and because of its history and heritage, I think the place could do better. Having said that, it is certainly a considerable step up from the majority of large resorts on the SL coast.

text: As you enter, the view of the beautiful pool .... merging into a pristine beach ... merging into the sea sweeps you away. Unfortunately you don't get swept off your feet at this property. Since we didn't get a booking at the VIVANTA by Taj in Bentota we thought we'd try the Heritance. The property is run down and seems to have seen better days. A renovation should be on the cards sooner than later. We were upgraded to a suite named after the legendary Sachin Tendulkar but unfortunately the exhilaration of of the room or the hotel in no way matched the Little Master's batting. The room was ill-planned. No light switches and plug points in the right places, basins in which you couldn't splash your face, a Mini Bar fridge with a broken shelf, and never replenished, pathetic mal-functioning wifi...... and one could go on and on.... Minor glitches but collectively a huge nuisance for the price we paid. The biggest problem was the air-conditioning, never below 24 degrees Celsius. This in a hot and humid Bentota was a big problem. Two large swimming pools. Wow !! one for playing and kids and one for peaceful and serious swimmers like me. A Great idea! However the pleasure was short lived when we entered the pool. The water was cloudy and had particles flowing in it. Temperature was like soup. The Gym was exceedingly ill-equipped for the number of rooms. Only two treadmills, one of which was closed non-functional for the duration of my stay. One large dining area for buffets. One fine-dining restaurant but we never saw a living sole there in the 4 nights we spent. The food at the buffets were exceptional, but in case you're a vegetarian please be very careful. Options are very limited. Since large groups were coming in the buffet tables had huge queues. I for one am fond of nibbling tit bits going often to the table. But that was a Big no-no. Dealing with the lower staff is impossible. Not only is their a pathetic standard of English, many of them pretend to understand and say yes but things are not done. However I'd be failing in my duty if I didn't mention here, that the senior staff ably led by GM Mr Upul Peiris and the F&B Manager Gamini, were extremely courteous and helpful. Highly responsive. Problems brought to their notice were promptly attended to. I believe Mr Peiris has been here only for a few months. Seeing his leadership abilities and genuine concern for the customer I'm very sure these glitches should be a thing of the past very soon. The management needs to move from Responsiveness to Pro-activeness. My recommendation is to go here at a quiet time and not during peak season.

text: We travelled with family on an outing, that had been planned a couple of months in advance. One of the members of our party is in a wheelchair and from the time of booking, this was mentioned as a special request. However, it was extremely difficult in getting confirmation from the hotel (both head office and hotel were contacted) if they were able to accommodate this guest. Several calls and emails went ignored and we resorted to calling a friend. This was extremely annoying as full paying customers you would like to think that the hotel would want to provide you with this basic service. A complaint made to the FB page provided some call back, but as always the trail went cold. We were unsure as to if this guest was able to make it, so in sheer desperation we had someone physically visit the hotel the week prior to our holiday and ask if they could be shown a few of the room categories, we were happy to upgrade if necessary. However, the person was not shown all categories and so the guest decided to only come for the day. Needless to say, we went there already disappointed with what the hotel had to offer. Once we checked in, we realised that one of our rooms was able to accommodate the guest in the wheelchair, and then proceeded to go to great lengths to ensure this guest joined us for the night. When we questioned the front desk as to why this room had not been shown to us, we were not given a valid response and we let it be, as we felt like we had already exerted way too much effort in what was meant to be a relaxing holiday! Needless to say, I felt like reservations, front desk and the head office staff were negligent and incompetent in this regard. Thereafter our trip went along smoothly, the staff were friendly and courteous and cooperated with requests such as bringing out a birthday cake. The rooms were clean and the common areas pleasant. It is a decent family hotel. The food was average at best, with no real highlights. text: Heritance Ahungalla is always our first choice when I and my partner visit Sri Lanka. I have stayed in this hotel more than 20 times over the last few years and, there is nothing else in Sri Lanka to beat its architectural beauty, tranquility, beautiful sandy beaches, friendly staff and their hospitality, and great food choices. All our work stresses and worries just disappear into the thin air as soon as we walk into the lobby of the hotel for the first time. Friendly welcome from the staff and the glance of the hotel environment with the infinity pool and the sound of the sea waves set the tone for the rest of our holiday. We love to come to Herritance to celebrate Christmas and the New Year since they organise a fabulous dinner with amazing food buffet with ice sculptures and food decorations which is out of this world, dance shows, fireworks and music by a great band. This experience is heavenly under the stars with the sound of the sea. What is unbeatable in this hotel, compared to other hotels in Sri Lanka, is the friendliness and the quality of the staff who works their. This goes from the General Manager to all the managers, to the waiters who serve at the restaurant, to the cleaning staff, and to the pool staff. They are always their to do their best to make our stay a memorable experience. I would like to give a special mention to Duminda and Waruna at the restaurant who always made sure we have an amazing dinning experience. Rukmal, the towel artist, make fabulous animal figures with towels and surprise us every morning as we come back to our room after breakfast. Pool attendants are always there to prepare our sun-beds every morning. We love walking along the sandy beach in front of the hotel in the morning and also in the evening and enjoy the evening sunset and then dive into the pool for a final swim before getting ready for the dinner. One day we wanted to organise a special dinner on the beach for a friend and his family to celebrate his retirement. The staff went out of their way to organise this dinner with fabulous food and assigned dedicated staff to serve the food. It was an unforgettable experience. I recommend this for couples if you are interested in organising a romantic dinner or for any special events to mark the occasion. I hope to be back again in the summer to re-live this beautiful experience.

text: This ought to be a great hotel but it ends up only being a good one. It lets itself down on a couple of fronts. First the good - the food is excellent both in the main restaurant and the fine dining restaurant. In particular we were very impressed with the team that look after the pool bar and the fine dining room. Worthy of particular mention are the guys in Lakmal's team including Dilan, Kolitha and Silva who were chatty without being intrusive and went out of their way to help. Dinesh made sure that a birthday celebration in the fine dining restaurant was special and memorable. Also the pools are very large and the main pool is really beautiful. The hotel is justifiably proud of having been designed by Sri Lanka's most celebrated architect Geoffrey Bawa. The view as you arrive at reception is fantastic looking right through the hotel lobby and over the beach to the sea. Unfortunately our experience of the front desk staff is they manage to be both obsequious and a bit too full of how good they think the hotel is at the same time. We were particularly annoyed when they failed to pass on two important messages from our tour operator. The rooms also look the part at first but fall victim to style over substance. There are so many hotel 'ornaments' that you have to clear loads of stuff out of the way to put your own belongings away. The light over the desk is hung so low that you bang your head on it whilst it manages to keep the mirror above the desk in complete shade. You have to ring housekeeping to ask for many of the things we found provided automatically in other hotels such as adaptors and mosquito repellers. You also need to make use of the Do Not Disturb sign pretty much whenever you are in the room or you are likely to find your bed being turned down at 6 in the evening! We also experienced power failures on almost every evening - not the end of the world in themselves but it would have been nice to have had a torch in the room instead of sitting in complete darkness until the power came back on. The bathroom was one of the biggest disappointments as it only contain a shower. We asked twice about moving to a room with a bath and once were told there were no rooms with baths and the second time were asked for $100 per night to move to a room with a bath. On both occassions we were told we could use the jacuzzi near the resident's pool if we wanted a bath although we were never brave enough to stroll down there in the altogether with our soap and shampoo! The jacuzzi is actually a cheap plastic afterthought that would have Mr Bawa turning in his grave. In summary this hotel did not impress as much as other hotels we stayed in during our trip. It charged for things such as internet usage and had not done a great job of anticpating our needs in a way that other hotels did that did not cost anywhere near as much as this one and it would probably not be on our list of places to go back to or to recommend on that basis.

text: Okay it's one of the best hotel is Sri Lanka, it has won the award of best leisure hotel by the minister of tourism. Sure, the two pools are outstanding, the rooms are nice, the area is quiet and the beach is nice but... staying there we kept asking ourselves: is it how one should experience Sri Lanka beaches? Just before we stayed at Mirissa, a lovely beach with a lot of atmosphere, a couple small hotels and guest houses, a few waterfront bars and a great laid back atmosphere. The Heritance is the opposite. Big resort where you pay over-priced drink and food served by stylish staff. The hotel probably owns the beach, because there is nothing else around. Would advice to go there if you don't mind missing the charm of more "informal places". Compare to other places, we found the contact with the locals to be biased. It's either hotel staff or very insisting beach sellers. The later can be quite annoying especially when the seat in group of 8-10 just in front of your chair and stay all day long. The food was not exceptional, certainly not in line with the price they ask for it (in Sri Lankan terms of course!).

text: We stayed here for 4 nights at the end of our Sri Lanka trip in 2 rooms.impressive driveway and entrance lobby and friendly greeting and check in .Rooms are large and had good views to the garden and towards the sea, well equipped and very clean with great service from our daily room attendant, although on arrival both rooms had cockroaches but he dealt with these swiftly and they did not reappear, comfortable beds and nice linens and towels. No signage to any of facilities such as gym. Great pools and very spacious gardens and lots of sun beds with good service from pool attendants.The major disappointment was the attitude of bar staff and some of restaurant staff to all inclusive guests, unfriendly and unhelpful to the point of rudeness! Why offer an all inclusive option and then treat these guests as second class citizens? We were frequently ignored in the bar area and bills presented in a manner which suggested you shouldn't order anymore! Totally spoilt what otherwise would have been a very pleasant stay.

text: The room itself was okay, relatively clean and fair in size. My biggest issue with the stay was that, when relaxing or walking on the beach, there were around 15ish street merchants constantly harassing me and other guests to buy their clothes (at extortionate prices compared to going to a local shop or market), as well as being badgered to book tours, again at 2-3 times the price when booking away from the beach. I have to point out that these were not hotel employees, but independent traders whom for some reason had access to the hotel every day we stayed there. The hotel offers a baggage handling service where they will move your bags to and from your room for you free of charge, however, be vigilant as personal items were stolen from our luggage between us leaving the room to checkout, and our bags being moved by one of the staff members. In all honesty, I have stayed at many hotels in different countries and I would say, this is the one time I have gone on holiday and not felt like I was actually on holiday as there was just that much badgering going on that it was almost impossible to relax. Upon walking out of the front gates of the hotel, you would have 4-5 tuk tuk drivers ask and try to take you to places you have repeatedly told them you do not wish to go and although this is not the hotel's fault, when it happens every single day, I feel as though it has to be mentioned. Anyone considering going to Sri Lanka, I recommend it - just consider staying somewhere else because for me, this was a 5-star mistake.

text: We visited this hotel at the end of a group tour and were very disappointed with our accommodation. The other members of the group were given different quality rooms despite having paid the same and were mostly very happy but our room was unacceptable. ( I think from the website images it was a â€˜deluxeâ€™ room with partial sea view) The electrics in this part of the hotel were obviously in need of urgent renovation. Two of the plug sockets were damaged with melted plastic around the pin holes and the air conditioning would only work at all by fiddling with the slider switch on the wall and then went off again after a couple of minutes. We complained and a manager said they would sort out the plug sockets the next day but asserted that the air conditioning WAS working although obviously it was not and the room remained very warm. Apparently the hotel was fully booked and there was nothing he could do about it. I was online looking for alternative accommodation when the situation was resolved by our tour guide who generously swopped rooms with us and this room was lovely. Although the electrics were our main complaint, the room also smelled damp and was generally in need of renovation, not really five star. The rest of the hotel was very good and the restaurant was excellent so our experience was a great shame. (Although a word of caution re check out- all members of the group found that they had paid their bills in pounds with a poor exchange rate although the invoice was in rupees and nobody was asked about paying in sterling)

text: have just returned after two weeks at the heritance in AHUNGALLA.We had avery good holiday& the hotel staff were very friendly & helpfull.The only thing that let this hotel down was the rooms which are in dire need of refurbishment.The bathrooms have a half glazed screen with blinds which i found very odd.Some of the walls are finnished in a polished concrete effect , which might have been fashionable thirty years ago but not now.However i do not want to put people off this hotel because the rooms are still comfortable & functional. we found the food also very good with a good selection to suit all nationalitys.The service in the pool bar could be a little slow at times & we did feel that people who were not on all inclusive got a better service than people who were .The other down side to this hotel is the distance to the airport . This can take anything between two & three hours depending on the traffic & the time of day. To conclude i would not hesitate to recommend this hotel to my friends.

text: HOTEL: We stayed at the Heritance for 10 Nights. The hotel and staff are lovely. After reading a previous review about being to scared to leave the room, i feel that this is an insult the the hard working staff there. At no point did we feel we threatened by staff, housekeeping staff smiled and never asked for a tip and the same said with the staff in the bar area. I suppose the hotel could do with a lick of paint but as for broken sunbeds i didnt see any, and there was always loads to choose from. The only negative thing about the room is the size of the fridge which is very small. But again it wasnt a real problem. YES.. you tip for most things but we never felt preasured to do so, and even if you do its 100rs at a time! The sellers on the beach are a bit of a pain, but a firm no and they go off to the next person, and after a while getting the same response from us they didnt even bother. Our room was on the 3rd floor and it was lovely, and we even had our own little gekcho which was great for eating insects. Our room was cleaned twice a day with clean towels and more water. The food was lovely, the only downside is there isnt much options for vegitarians. The only major downside with ther Heritance was location. when we travel we like to go out and try local resturants which is why we booked b&b, however other then the little fish resturant (which is cheap with lovely food) along the beach there isnt anything walking distance. We did take a taxi RS3500 (that waited 3hrs and brought us back to the hotel) to Hikkaduwa where you'll find bars/resturants and several rotty cafe. If we'd of known this we would of booked HB as we ended up spending most evenings eating in the hotel. TOURS: We did several trips whilst in Sri Lanka. The first to Uda Walawe park, as much as it was a long drive it was lovely to see the elephants roaming around freely, its def worth a visit. We then did a 2 day trip to Kandy and Sigiriya again a lot of driving, we stopped off at a tea shop on the way which was ok, then the botanical gardens which is a lovely place to sit with an ice cream and watch the world go by. We then went to the temple of tooth which was lovely, and to be honest go without a guide as ours was a bit of an idiot trying to get us to pay for him to study etc etc.. which we felt was very cheeky whilst inside a buddhist temple!!! In Kandy We stayed at Chaaya Citadel which was lovely and great food, to be honest it was a shame we only stayed the night. The next day we had an early start and more driving to Sigiriya, this was via a spice market and to be honest at 830am we probably wasnt the most awake customers!! but we listened and left! Once we arrived at Sigirya we headed up the many steps in the mid morning heat!!! the views at the top are lovely and make for great photos, they even had a family of monkeys that live on the top. Then it was the 7hr drive back to the hotel. Be warned your driver will take you to various tea/gem and spice shops!!!! We asked our driver if we could skip these but its something they have to do, even though we put our foot down and said no to the gem store. Overall we enjoyed our stay at the Heritance and its lovely staff.

text: So it seems that even though we booked a 5â­ hotel, we were unlucky to get the most outdated dirty rooms I've ever seen in such highly rated hotel. I always judge my room by the condition of the bathroom. The bathrooms here in both rooms were so dirty. The shower was the worst. The shower screen was completely covered by soap scum. The tiles were mouldy. Clearly the housekeeping had not heard of bleach or sugar soap or any kind of deep cleaning. Even run down hotels can be presented well with proper maintenance & care. These rooms don't deserve anymore than 3â­ rating. Very disappointed. The food outlets however were fantastic. We dined at 3 outlets during our stay and each area was superb. Food was delicious. Best buffet food I've experienced this time in SL. The service was equally incredible. We travel with a toddler and we can demanding however the team made it so pleasant for us. Thanks you F&B team. Keep up the great work. You guys run a true 5â­ rated Hotel restaurant. Message to the Heritance brand. High time you pay attention to the condition of your rooms rather than leveraging off the great locations your hotels are based at.

text: We stayed here as part of a tour of Sri Lanka, finishing with a 5 night stay by the beach. Positives: the staff are friendly and try very hard. Food was plentiful and usually of good quality. The pools are very pleasant and well set out. The size of the room was good, and the aircon worked well without being too noisy. Drinks were reaonably priced - large beer Â£1.20, cocktail typically Â£3.75. Negatives: the building is over thirty years old and doesn't really look as though it has had a proper makeover at any time. It looks a bit tired. Although the staff try hard, they are bit chaotic and prone to mistakes when it is busy. On arrival, the wrong bags were sent to our room, and despite me making this clear, the porter seemed determined to leave them with me - a minor gripe, but typifies things. Drinks and food orders were wrong on occasions. I think that the food was pricey for Sri Lanka at Â£20 each for food from the buffet. Food at the buffet was not always piping hot, depending on what time we went. There is almost nothing to do outside the hotel. The "entertainment" in the evening is dire.

text: I booked three rooms at half-board and came with my wife, 20 month old daughter and wife's relatives for two nights in September 2013. I was keen to experience a Geoffrey Bawa architected hotel and was impressed by the thoughtfulness of his design. The hotel aims to merge with nature, and allow for breezes to flow throughout the compound, providing a natural cooling. There were two pools, which we well maintained and a great place to lounge through during the day. I was very keen to experience the food at the hotel - as I had heard that it was rated as one of the best dining resorts in Sri Lanka and I was not disappointed. I was struck by the thoughtfulness of the dishes in the Jute restaurant - and also couldn't recall any dish tasting bad. All the food was balanced and tasty. Even the Sri Lankan food was unbelievably good. The staff were helpful and always with a smile. Also enjoyed the gym, badmington court and table tennis facility in the venue. The only negative for me was the reasonable isolation of the resort. As I tend to always like to explore the surroundings, I was a bit disappointed when leaving the resort by the lack of facilities around walking distance of the hotel. Again that was my preference, but if you wish to travel and only stay in a resort to rest and relax it is a great place.

text: I have just returned form 10 days at the Heritance with my girlfriend and can honestly say there wasnt any aspect fo the hotel that was disappointing. I work for a top tour operator in england and have travelled around the world staying at many top hotels. The service at the Heritance matched, if not exceeded many of these. The pools were fantastic...clean, great suze and we had one of the two at leat to ourselves on many occasions..it was great!! Below are some further comments: Room - was brilliant. It was a great size, really nicely furnished, clean with a great bathroom. Great views to pool and ocean. Cleaned daily. Food - amazing! we were on ahalf board basis and te food was superb. Great choice, different them every day, fresh, beautiful curries! Service - amazing. The staff were so attentive it was incredible. They were polite and friendly all the time. They alwas say hello and and make a real rapport with you throughout the time we were there. Beach - lovely but you do get hounded a bit by the touts when you walk on it. Just ignore them if you want them to leave you alone. Theyre firendly though. The sea is a bit rough so you cant really swim in it. Touts - if you want to get a taxi just ask one of the touts for a tuk tuk Its so much cheaper than the hotel taxis. We had the same driver for the whole 10 days and he was great. He took us to lots of places cheaply and was a safe driver. Dont be scared to use one..youll probably be a bit nervous the first time you get in one but then you can get their number and as soon as you want to go somewheer give them a call and theyll come and pick you up. Overall..couldnt fault our time at the heritance in any way. Ive read some of the negative reviews on this site and cant really understand what theyre on about. One said this hotel was dated which is complete rubbish! Feel free to email me if you have any questinos or want to know more. Nick

text: We ended our tour around Sri Lanka with a couple of nights at the Heritance Ahungalla. The hotel is well situated by the beach and we enjoyed walking along the shore watching the ocean roll in. We arrived with high expectations given all the five star reviews, but our experience did not live up to this. The bathroom in our room was disappointing for a 5 star hotel - small, bare plaster (not sure whether the room was being redecorated or this was the intended 'vibe') and the door wedged on the floor every time you tried to open it. The handle came off a drawer in the bedroom as the staff showed us the room when we checked in. On a positive note, breakfasts were buffet style with a very wide selection. Rather than accept the 'special offer' to upgrade to half board on arrival, we ate a la carte for dinners which meant we could choose what we wanted and this turned out to be much more cost effective than the half board offer/buffet. When we ate at the Mustard the place was very quiet, but we were rushed by the waiting staff - main courses arriving when we were half through our starters and left on the table, and dessert offered and our plates whipped away as we enjoyed the last mouthful of main course. Why the experience had to be rushed when the place was far from busy I don't know, perhaps the service could be most generously described as 'over eager'. This is a good hotel in a nice location. Staff were friendly. Just a few things which meant that our experience was not 5 star.

text: The hotel looks lovely and the rooms are very nice - large, airy and tastefully furnished in a modern take on traditional. Wonderful big comfortable bed, excellent rain shower, big flat screen TV, minbar, generous safe and covered private balcony. Public areas are open plan and also look very nice - until you spot the package operator signs & programs, hear the scream of children in the pool (right beside the only bar & lounge) and realise the predominant language is Russian. Service is hit and miss - there are some excellent staff who cannot do enough to please, but there is also a lot of inexperience and a shortage of staff for the number of guests - leading to some extremely poor service experiences (eg. Wine ordered at dinner not arriving until after dessert; dirty plates left on tables for long periods; tables not properly cleaned between use; buffet dishes not replenished; etc.) The food quality in the buffet is poor - tough cuts of meat, over cooked curries and left out/not refreshed very often. Even at the fresh food stations the ingredients were not top quality and over cooked - and at best all the dishes are luke warm. Breakfast was no better - some good curries, but otherwise heavy doughy croissants, â€˜butterâ€™ that was in fact margarine, a couple of cheap jams, limited selection of fruit and one person cooking eggs and another cooking hoppers for the 100s of guests. To round it off - the majority of the wine list was unavailable (excuse being difficulty with supply chain due to pandemic - but the other hotels on our tour hadnâ€™t suffered the same problems), as were a number of items on the pool bar snack menu. The sl a carte restaurant and the other bars / coffee shop werenâ€™t open either. Definitely not a five star experience.

text: Absolutely wonderful! The resort was a tranquil haven set away from the busy main road and made you feel like you have just stepped into paradise. The hotel is beautifully laid out, allowing you to go from swimming in the pool to swimming in the ocean with just a few steps along a very private beach. The architecture is stunning. The hotel had a wide array of amenities like 2 pools (one with Jacuzzi), bars, restaurants, a library, tennis court, spa, putting green, gym, loads of games, etc which I felt made it ideal for either couples or families. There were always activities for both children and adults like mask painting, water aerobics, traditional dances, etc but they were unobtrusive, allowing you to either be entertained or just relax in peace around the pool, without being bothered. The rooms were beautiful, comfortable and cleaned spotlessly every day. The service was outstanding with smiling happy faces greeting you wherever you go. Nothing seemed too much trouble to do and they made you feel like you were part of the family, not just an anonymous guest. Special thanks to KK who made us feel like we were royalty every day and went out of his way to help us experience Sri Lankan culture. The food was spectacular with a wonderful mix of Sri Lankan and international dishes. We were mad about the Egg hoppers and wonderful Sri lankan curries with their endless choice of sambals, chutneys, pickles, pitu, etc. This is a wonderful escape that makes you feel absolutely pampered every step of the way.

Location is beautiful and rooms are good. Need to improve in food and urgency of staff In getting things done.

text: My wife and I had a two week holiday here in December. Weather was good and we did trips to Yala National Park (4 hours by car) and Kandy (4 hours by car). I list below the positives and the negatives of our holiday. Positives : Good food in restaurant buffet with a different daily menu. Friendly and generally helpful staff throughout the hotel. Excellent sea view from our first floor bedroom balcony. Excellent sea front location offering lovely beach walks. Two very large and spacious swimming pools kept clean. Room very clean and some wonderful animal shaped towels kept us amused. International plug sockets, always a help. Good size balcony. Much needed cold drinks upon arrival. Clean sheets and towels daily. Large 50" TV in bedroom. (A negative for us as we don't watch TV but probably a positive for others). Plenty of colourful bird life in the hotel grounds. And so to the negatives. No Jacuzzi for our entire stay. When we enquired we were told they were waiting for a part but by the time we left the Jacuzzi was looking very grubby with gathered dropped leaves and rainwater. Alcoholic drinks were expensive particularly a small glass of wine with dinner. Costly alcoholic drinks turned up very quickly at dinner but not the free water. On several occasions I had to ask three times for water. Lack of local railway train information at reception. No postcards sold at the hotel. We had air conditioning problems in our room which took a while to resolve. The plug in the wash basin didn't operate properly. No curtain in the bathroom for the first three days of our stay. Wobbly fan on the ceiling (maybe it was meant to be like that !). Wobbly bedside table definitely shouldn't be like that. Nowhere to walk to / have a coffee/beer/snack out the front of the hotel (busy road). That's even if you manage to get past the tour guides who hover by the hotel gates. Lack of lighting at night between the hotel front and the hotel gates. Insufficient staff in the restaurant when busy. This was particularly noticeable at weekends. Noisy building work being carried out on one wing of the hotel during the day. Some of these points might seem petty but added together it wasn't the holiday my wife and I had hoped for. Would definitely recommend Yala National Park. A visit to a Turtle hatchery. The Botanical gardens at Kandy. The fort at Galle .

of colourful bird life in the hotel ground and so to the negative no jacuzzi for our entire stay when we enquired we were told they were waiting for a part but by the time we left the jacuzzi wa text: Heritance Ahungalla is not by any standards a 4,5 star hotel. We have chosen it for our honeymoon trip as pictures seen on the website looked amazing and we also read many good reviews. However, our stay there turn out to be a great dissapointment and we won't be going back. To list just few problems you may encounter there : it is impossible to go for a walk on the beach as you are constantly pestered by locals who do not take no for an answer; cockroaches can be found not only on hotel corridors but also inside the rooms; the cutlery served at tables has leftovers of food stuck to it; the bed linen in the rooms as well as the curtains are stained and often with holes; the hotel provides hardly any toiletries and if so, they are stuck on the bottom of a ceramic bottles in a very small quantitiy; there are constant problems with electricity and it can go off for over 30mins at time. As for the service it is probably one of the most tiresom and annoying problems of all, as there is no communication between the team members serving meals in the restaurant, you need to ask several times for a pot of coffee or a bottle of water, provided that you will be understood by the waiter on the first occassion. If so, the requested drink may not be delivered at all, while few other team memers will approach with exactly the same question about your choice of drink but it will take ages for someone to actually deliver it to the table. The tips are expected while the service quality or rather its lack, does not jusitfy it at all. The most imposing are often the housekeeping supervisors (not the regular housekeepers- they work very hard and hardly ever strike a conversation with a guest), who can follow you down the corridor repeating few times that they are entirely responsible for cleaning your room....all obviously to be tipped. In case of any problems with the room calling reception is normally a waste of time, as you have to call back several times before someone turns up to deal with the problem. The hotel is full of damp and looks as if its times of glory have long gone. We have been travelling extensively over last couple of years throughout Africa and Asia and we are very much aware of difficulties some developing countries face, however we cannot find an explanation for advertising a very poor quality hotel as a 4,5 star resort.

text: Having spent many holidays along the beautiful west coast of Sri Lanka, trying out the various hotels over the years, I can honestly say that Heritance Ahungalla is my favourite. Convenient to get to from Colombo on the new Expressway, it is situated about 90 kilometers from Colombo. From the moment I drive up to the entrance with the fantastic view right up to the sea, I feel at home. There is such a feeling of peace and serenity with the warm yet gentle welcome from the staff. I have requested sea view rooms and have never been disappointed. Room 305 is my favourite. If you like tasty food and lots of it, Heritance Ahungalla is the place to be. I think their chefs are about the best in Sri Lanka. The buffet has a huge selection of dishes to please the western and local palate. The salads varied and desserts yummy. Heritance has two attractive large swimming pools, and also a very attractive beach. The seas around Sri Lanka can be dangerous around monsoon time, but if you love messing around in the shallow water, going for long walks or just sun bathing it is wonderful. I strongly recommend Heritance Ahungalla, if you want a relaxing holiday. I always come away feeling rested and energized wishing I could stay longer! Elizabeth Gunewardene

text: We decided to stay at Heritance Ahungalla as it was designed by an architect that we like - Geoffrey Bawa. Later we realized so are many hotels en route Ahungalla from Colombo. Having said that, it sure is a beautiful hotel with two vast pools overlooking the beach. The brand is all about the blend of tradition and modernity. The service staff were all in their white sarongs with white shirts. The rooms were a bit disappointing. We requested for a triple room and realized that it is a double with an extra bed. We really thought there would be more space. The maintenance was not as good and lamp shades were falling off. For a property of that size and price the in-room amenities were dated including a large tube television that juts into the walk path. There were a lot of renovation going on and we had to walk through scaffolding all the time. We also had this noon drills and plumbing noise that would not let us take that much needed siesta. The food was again a strong blend of Lankan and Continental. I was ok with an odd piece of dried fish in my food. My wife and kids were not. So I had to taste the dishes before they ate. But the traditional food was enjoyable and we gorged. There is a fine dining restaurant in the property and I would rate that very high. The pools were fabulous - clean, well maintained and addictive. The gym was old, grubby and rusted (most of the equipment were not usable). When we go to Sri Lanka again we will not go south as it is intended to rip off unsuspecting tourists. And so we will not stay at Heritance Ahungalla either. I think all properties in that stretch of Bentota, Ahungalla are overrated. I would rather stay in a boutique property at Fort Galle.

text: We stayed here for 2 weeks at the end of March and first week of April. Mostly, I would agree the previous writer's review. If you wish to really see Sri Lanka then I would suggest that you stay here at the end of your holiday as it is quite far south and means that travel to places such as Kandy are extremely long and tiresome and the driving is something else to be seen, I would describe it as a 'white knuckle ride'!. The hotel is well designed but I would struggle to place it in the 4-5* bracket (try out hotels in Malaysia and you will really see the difference). There is a so called shop in the hotel which really does not sell any essentials such as shampoo so make sure you take your own hair products. Also, we bought factor 40 sun tan cream which did not work and we were severely burned (another couple had the same experience) so again, make sure you take your own sun tan creams and after sun with you. Regarding the beach terrorists, they do hassle you. We were followed for an hour on the beach by 5 of them who just would not give up, no matter how politely you said you weren't interested. They called and shouted to you if you were sunbathing near the beach and the only thing to do was to completely ignore them. One day we went outside the hotel to go the the pharmacy to buy some after sun lotion (due to the rubbish cream the shop had sold) and found exactly the same hassle, we lasted about 20 minutes before going back to the hotel. Our room smelled damp when we initially entered and the air con never seemed cool, the staff knocked on the door daily, sometimes 4-5 times to check the room was ok. However, I think this had more to do with wanting a tip. One time they completely ignored the 'do not disturb sign' and still persisted. The restaurant did offer a very good selection (buffet style) and quality of food, the only thing that let it down was the length of time it took you to get a drink when requested, especially as the ratio of staff to customers was overwhelming at times. If you don't like being hassled then maybe this isn't the place for you. In terms of the staff, all were very friendly and polite apart from one or two who seemed to have tipping on their agenda as a priority more than genuine customer service. All in all, a good quality hotel but if they really wish to put themselves in the 4-5* bracket, they are missing a lot of extras which you would normally expect.

text: This is a strange one, to be sure. With a few tweeks it could be one of the best beach hotels you'll ever stay in anywhere, but in the comparison with other places we stayed in Sri Lanka (and particularly Mount Lavinia), it just seems to fall short in areas that it would be so easy to correct. The setting, design and physical feel of the hotel are all quite stunning. But right away you get those little irksome contrasts that make this a frustrating place. Complacency abounds and you sense that they are still all patting themselves on the back for being able to re-open after the devastation of the Tsunami (yes those dreadful Youtube videos from Boxing Day 2004 were from balconies at The Triton, which has now become The Heritance). Positive sentiment isn't quite enough at the 5 star level unfortunately. It sits behind a gorgeous stretch of beach with surf that you just are dying to play in just 50 feet away - but to get from hotel gardens to the sea, you have to pass an almost comically persistent group of beach tradespeople each time. The hotel has a line of flags to keep them at bay, but the security staff still let them bother you from a distance when you are on a sun lounger by the pool. Would you get accosted by a panhandler on the steps of the Waldorf Astoria as you left to get in your cab? The sidewalk is public space but things can be done..... The two pools are large and magnificent, with the green pool so huge it even allows you to "length swim". There is also a gym with fairly up to date equipment, but its functionality was comprised every day of my stay by an inability of staff to get the message (despite 3 reminders in 3 days) that the aircon needs to be on and set to below 28 degs C for anyone to be able to use it. The minimalist design of the public areas has an overall calming effect on you, but with the architect apparently having a veto on everything, this extends to a lack of many of the features that you expect in any large resort - an excursions / news board; signs to different areas; names on the bars etc. We had little to complain about the food. In fact it was fairly reasonably priced for a putative 5 star, but it had little real wow factor, and apart from some of the local dishes on the buffet menu, it just scraped by. Last year we stayed on Meeru Island resort in the Maldives and despite the obvious abundance of produce in Sri Lanka compared to a coral attol, Meeru's buffets were both more inspiring and much cheaper. The room was spacious with a big balcony - as it should be for just over $300 a night! But the bathroom was blatantly unfinished with two walls smooth plastered but not painted. Some guests demanded a room change for this - we were told it was a design feature (see photo). With such a huge balcony a sun lounger rather than just 2 chairs and a table would have been an idea. And why oh why was there no rack to dry wet clothes. There was plenty of space, but maybe the architect had his say there as well. All the staff we interacted with were cheerful and accommodating, apart from the reception staff who were a bit feckless and needed to be a little more proactive. We were invited to a cocktail party given by the assistant manager, and found him charming and with an earnest concerned approach to some of the criticisms we gently raised. It really did not sit well however to be told that the beach sellers were tolerated on a "better the devil you know" basis and that other "newer" nationalities amongst the clientele liked having them around. I am not so sure the Heritance is that well advised to try to imitate Sharm El Sheikh at these prices. Lose the traditional customer base and I think they will lose much of their trade to the likes of Mount Lavinia. If you were to stay here and, as we are, you are fairly easy going if the weather is good, (as it was), you will probably be happy enough at the Heritance, give or take the $100 or so a night that should still be in your wallet. But I can imagine it could quite quickly become a nightmare in bad weather. You even had to pay to play on the pool table. Free pool if you spend 1500 rupees on drinks - come on! To end on a positive note of a review which I had intended to be somewhat more complimentary than it has turned out, the laissez-faire approach has allowed wildlife to remain on the grounds undisturbed. To see massive Iguanas digging for crabs next to your sun-lounger while chipmunks frolic around on your umbrella stand is a uniquely warming feeling. We were even able to film troupes of monkeys and even pass them mango pieces to eat on the branches of trees by the pool. Enchanting.

text: Spent 7 nights at the hotel at the beginning of February. Enjoyed: the food, the pools (particularly the one with the leaning tree), the sound of the ocean waves crushing on the shore, the spa, the beautiful sunsets from the room balcony and generally the great feeling of being in Sri Lanka in a beautiful hotel. Did not enjoy: the monitor lizards walking around, (did not know they would be there and just got terrified when I saw the first one strolling around the beach!!!), the overwhelming strenght of the ocean waves which prevents you from swimming, the beach ladies constantly calling you in order to sell you something.

text: One thing which makes Heritance Hotels stand out is the food and hospitality. So I had high expectations. I have already been to Kandalama and Negambo, in both cuisine and hospitality is great and flawless. The first thing I noted is that they (Heritance Ahungalla) cannot handle a crowd. No welcome drinks for some of the guests. Very few (sometimes none) food options to vegetarians. The restaurant space was not enough when crowded. Service is really bad at the restaurant. Several times we had to ask for water and wait for it. Both Negambo and Kandalama is excellent in service where they event do not let the water glass finish in any of the tables. So lot of improvement is needed. And it is noted that the service is delayed not because the staff is very busy, but because there are some idle staff as well. More organization is needed. Rooms are okay. The first day there were only one shower cap in the room. The other shower cap box is empty. On top of that, the second day, there were no soap. Even the soap from the previous day has been removed. Location is okay. Nice pools. If the main is crowded or sunny in the day you can use the other pools.

text: Heritance Ahungalla offers the best in everything; rooms, beach & pool views, food, and cleanliness. The rooms & washrooms are extremely spacious & tidy. And the staff at the reception are very warm & welcoming! Only suggestion - make sure to segregate the veg options with a proper display. Veg sushi had the display but was mixed with seafood & chicken, and sadly even the chef couldn't figure it out until he tasted it & then confirmed.

text: Overpriced and definately not luxury
cleaned_text: overpriced and definately not luxury

text: The beginning of the holiday started in a very disappointing way. We arrived at the hotel at 2PM on time for check in. However we were informed that the rooms were not ready. As a result we had to wait for over two and a half hours to get our rooms which was a very disappointing experience to start a vacation. The excuse given by the staff was that the guests have not vacated the rooms on time. This is not a plausible excuse. The hotel should know when to call and inform guests that they need to check out on time. The least they could do then is call us and let us know there is a delay so that we can plan to arrive late to the hotel. My mother who is elderly had to sit for along time in the reception area and found it difficult to walk afterwords as well. We actually decided never to come back to this hotel again but we changed our minds after the experience afterwards. The staff in the hotel mainly the room maintenance and restaurant staff were very polite friendly and courteous. Never before had we experienced such a good service from staff in any other hotels we had been to. Another plus point was the food. The food was excellent. There was a wide variety and it was very tasty. One negative aspect is that we stayed one night on a day where there were less guests. On this day the food variety was not there and that was a bit of a undermining experience for us. Another unsatisfactory experience I faced was with the pool attendant. When I went to the swimming pool I asked the pool attendant for a towel. His reply was that the hotel had instructed him to inform guests to bring their room towels. This seemed very odd to me as I saw other patrons having pool towels. Anyway I proceeded to have a swim and I could not dry myself as I had no towel and I had to go to the room all wet. With the cold wind blowing I could have got pneumonia as well but thankfully that didn't happen. Later on I called the reception to clarify this and they said that the pool attendant should have given me towels and that he had given me false information. In any case I do hope the hotel takes this experience as a learning and inform their pool attendants as to not to refuse to give patrons pool towels. Finally I would like to say that the hotel did allow us to have a late check out in order to compensate for the delayed check in. Overall I would say that I would come back to Heritance Ahungalla due to the friendly and polite staff and the good food. However I hope that I will not face the unpleasent expeirnces I mentioned above, the next time I visit.. Dilshan Thambawita

text: Arriving at this hotel, it looked rather impressive with its long entrance and infinity pool overlooking the beach and ocean. On closer consideration, expecting five star quality, I was surprised to see stagnant water in some of the fountains, the quality of the material used in the hallways of the hotel looked rather cheap and our room, while quite big and comfortable seemed kind of empty (as if some furniture had been removed or was mssing something). The hotel food was average (which was how I found most of the food during our stay in Sri Lanka). For the positive, we loved the beautiful beach, which was one of the highlights of our trip, the greenery surrounding the pool areas and the natural beauty of it all, was what finally made our stay quite enjoyable (as well as the geckos wandering around). To reiterate, our room was very comfortable, clean and quite large for the three of us, with a very nice, large bathroom. We had a balcony overlooking the pool area and we could hear the waves of the ocean (unfortunately as of the evening we could not leave the doors opened because of the mosquitos).
