text: As we pulled up outside the entrance to this hotel we were amazed at the view. We were looking forward to some relaxing days. We were shown to our room which was disappointing. It had a poor view and the shower was in need of some good quality cleaning products, with the grouting all black and the glass door was covered in limescale. We were so unhappy and disappointed (this was the third hotel in the group that we've stayed at on this trip) that we asked to be moved to a different room. This was facilitated but we had to wait almost two hours for the replacement room to be ready. This room had a much better outlook and whilst the grouting was cleaner, there was still the same issue with the shower door. Some good limescale remover used regularly would work wonders. That said, the overall cleanliness of the room was very good. The room cleaning service was always good and the guys couldn't have been more helpful. The pool and gardens are nice and the staff at the pool were very good. On one occasion a man was in difficulty in the pool having wandered out of his depth, and the lifeguard on duty leaped to his aid. A happy ending. Don't be too worried if you see chipmunks and land monitors passing by. Perhaps even the occasional monkey. We found the service at the pool bar to be friendly but quite slow, with some staff, on occasion, preferring to stand and chat together. We ate in the outdoor restaurant twice and found the food to be pretty awful. After those poor experiences we ate in the buffet restaurant. I wish I could be more positive but I can only be honest - the evening meals were not up to the level of that at the previous hotel at which we'd stayed. We found many dishes overcooked and almost cold. At the dessert bar, only half the items were labelled, and if you went to eat after the main rush it felt like we were being given the leftovers. The whole presentation was lacklustre. The staff though, were very nice and friendly and the service good, though some worked harder than others. I feel this establishment would benefit greatly from more staff training and motivation.

text: This hotel was a bit of a disappointment, not the five star rating we were expecting. In our opinion this hotel needs to be downgraded to four star. Whilst there was some painting/maintenance work taking place while we were there, the hotel didnâ€™t have that â€˜luxuriousâ€™ five star feeling about it. Certainly comparing it to a five star rated hotel we stayed in whilst holidaying in Zanzibar 18 month's ago, it was definitely of a different class/standard. The fruit bowl, dressing gowns and slippers were not in our room when we arrived and there was no mention, when we checked in, of them arriving later. The cream rug was filthy (we rolled it up and put it under the bed) and that improved the look of the room immediately! On the plus side, the staff were extremely friendly and helpful and very responsive to our needs. On several occasions we only had one bath towel left instead of two which meant having to call house-keeping. Although immediately we called the second towel would rapidly appear, this isn't the level of service we would expect from a five star resort. The restaurant areas were nice and the food was good. We tended to eat in the coffee shop which also served as a restaurant which did some nice meals, we did eat occasionally in the buffet restaurant. The pool area is nice. The hotel is located on the beach, but most of the time the red flags are flying due to the under currents there. On most days despite the red flag flying people still went into the sea, if you went with caution you were fine, but there were occasions people got into difficulties and the life guard at the hotel had to come to their rescue. We enjoyed watching a wedding take place whilst there. We also had the experience of seeing one of the resident monitor lizards digging up and eating another monitor lizardâ€™s eggs (13 in all!!!). We were lucky enough to see a turtle come ashore and lay her eggs on the beach before going back out to sea â€“ wow what a wonderful experience. We also visited a turtle hatchery up the road, take a tuk tuk (itâ€™s cheaper than a taxi) and if you want to experience putting baby turtles into the sea you need to go at dusk around 6.00 pm (in Feb). Before booking this hotel we were told we could go out of the hotel and that there were lots of eating places in the area, this is not the case. We were told not to go out of the resort at night, so that was also disappointing. Sadly there is no â€˜all inclusiveâ€™ option here. In summary, this is a nice hotel, situated on a lovely beach, not five star luxury, but a nice four star. We were here celebrating my 50th birthday and wanted a bit of luxury after touring for 8 nights and in retrospect wish we had stayed at either The Jetwing Lighthouse or The Fortress in Galle.

text: Stayed in the Heritance Anhungalla for six nights in September. It is a smart stylish hotel designed by Bawa, Sri Lanka's foremost architect. Some may find it a bit stark and white, we loved it. The rooms were large with a lot of character; comfortable beds and a very diligent roomboys. Food in the main restaurant was buffet style with lots of choice and some interesting Sri Lankan dishes. Prices are a bit on the high side, there is a cheaper restaurant but the menu was limited. There are two pools, one is reserved for reidents, they have weekend visitors who can use the other pool. It is quite a large hotel but still got a bit crowded when they had a convention at the weekend. There are fabulous sunsets out to sea. The beach is heavily occupied by traders, the ladies have some good scarves and sarongs at cheap prices, guys want to sell you a boet ride or visit the restaurant down the beach. Some of our party did and found it very good and cheap. The beach boys are very polite, as are all Sri Lankans that we met and if you say you just want to be quiet and don't want to talk they leave you alone. The beach drops sharply into the sea and waves were popwerful so bathing is banned. This is one of the drawbacks of the hotle. The other problem is that there is nowhere to walk outside the hotel, if you venture out of the gate swarms of helpfull people appear! I think it's a great hotel for three or four nights, we got a bit bored after that.

text: A Geoffrey Bawa hotel on the coast of Sri Lanka. There are some real highlights: smooth, cool design, excellent swimming pool, fantastic location next to the beach. And some lows: the horrible smoke-filled restaurant (we had to ask for Sri Lankan dishes: they aren't always offered), irritating piped music, dodgy evening karaoke-style entertainer (though, to be fair, some guests seemed to enjoy it), and inadequate wi-fi. I would liked to have given this hotel 3.5 stars, since it is better than "average", but that doesn't seem to be available.

text: Overall a very good hotel and staff were excellent. Some areas of the hotel were tired but everywhere was very clean. Rooms were comfortable and facilities good, with a reasonably well equipped gym and two large pool areas, where the attendants were helpful in providing towels and arranging beds. The food was very good however, our experience in the dining room was mixed, mainly because at the weekend, the hotel is open to non-residents, so there were suddenly huge numbers of extra diners for dinner on Saturday and breakfast on Sunday, which turned the experience into a bit of a bun fight. The quality of the food was still good, however the presentation was off putting as staff could not keep up with the volume and serving dishes were left messy and tables were not cleared as quickly as on other days. We ended up in the 'outside area' which felt very 'make shift' - perhaps this area should be made available for non residents so that residents at the hotel do not experience reduced standards at the weekend. On the plus side, there is a quieter residents only pool, so it is possible to escape during the day at the weekend. My advice would be to avoid weekends when the hotel is open to non-residents as it becomes far too busy and noisy, specifically in the dining area.

text: We stayed here, and It was an amazing experience. The staff was excellent and the service was remarkable. The issue we had, however was the pool. There were people in the pool wearing ordinary clothes. Which is so off-putting and unhygienic. You are supposed to wear swimming attire and wash yourself before getting into the pool. This made us feel very uncomfortable and surprisingly the hotel management didn't seem to take notice of it either. Then when we went to the second pool, there was another couple the lady was dipping with her clothes on! This is not the type of environment we expect from a classy hotel. I really hope that the management takes required steps and fix the issue. Other than that it was a great stay and an extremely hospitable hotel.

text: Having had our honeymoon at the Heritance Kandalama 6 years ago, during this years' vacation to Sri Lanka we decided to experience another Heritance Hotel with our families and we are more than happy over the stay at Heritance Ahungala. The pictures do not do justice to the beautiful landscape and ofcourse the highly commendable team; the excellence of service by the Aitken hotel staff is something I always admire. Very smooth checking & checkout with special thanks to the Front office Manager Lakshitha who was very informative about the services offered and organized everything for us. Tharindu we will never forget your sincere smile and the service. We were offered a lovely cake congratulating for our 6th wedding anniversary. The surprise birthday cake for my brother in law was also well presented and special thanks goes to the Restaurant & Bar Manager Thushara, Madu, Panditha and of course Chef Thilakaratne you are doing an amazing job to make sure the team is serving the best food and tirelessly looks into making a happy dining experience. We really loved the food and the variations (makes me wanna go back!) The "yare tea" at breakfast was something to remember and loved the variety of hoppers (yum "pani appe" after ages!) Of course we will come again. You will not regret a long stay over here with delectable food, easy access to the beach, 2 beautiful pools (loved the green pool), outdoor sauna, well equipped gym, and within close proximity to attractions like madu river safari, turtle hatchery, & less than an hours' drive to Galle.

text: My husband and I are seasoned travellers to Sri Lanka and the Indian sub-continent. We are just finishing a 4 week trip to probably one of the best hotels on the Island if you are looking for a beach holiday. Without exception all the staff are absolutely wonderful - if only we could 'bottle' their smile before returning to the UK? The management readily admit that they need to update the bedrooms and public areas of the hotel but this in no way detracts from the amazing stay you will have from the minute you arrive until the very last minute before you leave. All staff are worthy of mention but as we do not have room to name them all, 3 in particular will ensure your stay remains not just an experience but a long lasting memory (KK Restaurant Manager; Nihal Restaurant Supervisor and Saman (our houseboy for Room 102). The lifeguards at the poolside also deserve a mention; not all guests are easy to deal with but they remain polite and cheerful whatever the guest request! The hotel, originally designed by Geoffrey Bauer has pride of place on a wide, long stretch of sandy and 'sun bed free' beach. Part of me doesn't want to write this review and to share my holiday with you - the only reason being we don't want lots of people to spoil it!! So enjoy - you will not be disappointed and if you are wondering if we will return - of course!

text: So much to say. The rooms were great, try for 3rd floor oceanview. The service was excellent. So many people to thank for our stay Klarathna, thushara, nerosh, varuna.. too many. Most particularly the front desk staff.. we toured sri lanka from Columbo to kandy to Penwalla to Nuwary Eliya to the hikkaduwa/batouna/Galle area. We had reservations with airbnb, and several hotels. When we arrived at the coast area we found none of the houses or hotels were anything like the websites depicted. All were filthy and trash strewn and very small. We came upon Heritance and were stunned . The hotel grounds are lush and clean, the pools were immaculate and the beach was clean large and perfect! There were multiple restaurants and bars on the grounds. There was entertainment . We stayed 4 days three nights and did not regret it. It should be said unless you a very comfortable with local foods and living conditions, this is the only hotel resort that offered a respite from the congestion and sanitary problems you may not be accustomed to. The hotel is also ideally centered between Columbo and Galle . We looked at almost every resort from Botouna to Galle, physically , while scrambling to find a place after being disgusted by our original "resort" this is far and away the best, by leaps and bounds . It is a five start resort at economy prices. ( we booked online in the lobby for a significantly reduced rate ) We also did half board which gave us breakfast and dinner. (We found this to be essential and we'll worth the little extra it cost) You will find the food choices were great and varied and the staff would accommodate any and all special requests. I wanted chicken noodle soup one night as opposed to the two choices and they made me a batch

Good entertainment afternoon and evening, fire works, shows , music etc.Something special was the man playing flute in the morning at the main pool.What was not good at all, was the great quantity of russian, ukrain and soviet people, noisy,arrogant,impolite, mainly dressed with shorts, shirts withouth sleeves and sandals, and all this at the main restaurant. Also a great deal of small children were roaming shouting and screaming in the main restaurant sometimes . In a 5 star hotel this is not acceptable!!!! In any case this hotel is good and advisable. bruno e marisella torino italia

text: This hotel was a great disappointment for us. This was our sixth night in Srilanka and when we made the bookings we were so excited about this hotel and the photos we have seen. However, our stay there was a disaster! We waited for more than 30 mins to Check in. When we checked it, the room was in a mess and the telephone lines were not working. We complained to the reception and all they said that this was because of the rain and it will come back within 10 mins but it didn't. We tried again but it was useless. The receptionist and the staff were rude and their service was far below the standards. to make things worse, there was a school trip that night and the kids occupied the swimming pool, the restaurant and everywhere in the hotel. The restaurant was expensive and the food was average but the service was a little bit better than anywhere else in the hotel. The room was small but the balcony was nice. In general I would not recommend this hotel to anyone. If you still want to go there, then please ensure that you are in the middle of the week and not on Saturday/Sunday or Friday to avoid the busy times at the hotel where the service drops down to the lowest level.

text: Unless your dream holiday is to sit by a pool all day with staff continually at beck and call this isn't for you. There is very little to do around the hotel unless you have a car or a driver. we found ourselves getting rather bored of it, quite quickly. The hotel is on a stunning sandy beach but you cannot swim in the sea, and the areas round the two pools are full of Russians with money to burn. I don't like customers being rude to staff but saw plenty of this. However staff accepted it due to massive tips and pretty much ignored everyone else. Food in the hotel was good and rooms were clean but wouldn't go back. The whole hotel was pretty impersonal with massive long white corridors which reminded me of Victorian hospitals. This hotel was the final one on our trip so we only stayed two nights, which for us was one night too many. As I said in my intro the hotel was perfect if you want to spend all day on a sun lounger but it didn't suit us.

text: We stayed one night (full board) in a Premium room. The entrance to the hotel was impressive. We were very satisfied with the detailed security check that was done on arrival considering the prevailing situation in the country. The welcome was warm and friendly. Our room was comfortable. The restaurant was ok and food was good. The restaurant manager was very friendly. The hotel has two pools, thus making the pools less crowded at a given time, despite the number of guests. The beach was spectacular! It was a gloomy evening and we walked about 10 minutes to the North (as recommended by hotel staff) and came upon some cliffs that gave the most spectacular views of the ocean! Since we checked in on a week day, we were able to relax and spend a peaceful day. I heard it gets busier during weekends.

text: **Google Review for Heritance Ahungalla** Heritance Ahungalla is a stunning resort with a private beach and well-maintained pools. The rooms are neat, and the overall environment is clean and family-friendly. Itâ€™s a great place for a vacation with kids. However, the service leaves much to be desired. At check-in, the front desk staff greet you warmly and create an impression of excellent service, but the actual intention to help seems to be lacking. We traveled as two families and requested rooms close to each other. The staff promised to accommodate us the next day, but despite multiple follow-ups, no one informed us why it wasnâ€™t arranged. Additionally, there were several service lapses: - When we reported non-functional TV services, no one responded. - An emergency housekeeping request was ignored until we followed up repeatedly every 30 minutes. - A simple request for bananas for a child after the paid breakfast buffet had closed was also ignored, with staff disappearing without fulfilling the request. While the staff are polite and pleasant in interactions, their inability to provide timely and reliable service is disappointing for a five-star resort. Compared to the service at The Kingsbury Colombo, Heritance Ahungalla falls significantly short. Overall, a beautiful property with potential, but the service experience needs serious improvement to match its five-star rating.

text: From the moment you arrive till the time you leave this fabulous hotel with its attentive, friendly and engaging staff never fails to impress. Our large airy room overlooked the main pool and beach and when not walking the golden sands or wallowing in the pool or relaxing in the shade of the trees around the second pool there was nothing better than sitting on the balcony enjoying a drink and listening to the nightly music from below. The breakfast buffet was huge. Well laid out and fresh daily. The food in the restaurants was well presented and tasty. My favorite, the Mexican with Sri Lankan influence menu. Ate there twice, different courses both times, everyone of them delicious. Would I return. In a heartbeat.

text: My husband and I had 2 magical nights away at Ahungalla in between our busy wedding week in Dec 13. We were incredibly well looked after from the moment we arrived. From the welcome drinks in the foyer to the quick and friendly check-in, the staff were always polite, friendly and helpful. We were very pleased to have received an upgrade to our room with a lovely view. The swimming pool, beach access and general atmosphere all contributed to a wonderful stay but the highlight of the trip has to be the amazing food! All three meals were of a very high standard, we were very impressed and thoroughly spoilt for choice. I will gladly go back to Heritance Ahungalla anytime I visit Sri Lanka in the future!

text: A country full of lovely friendly people with happy smiling faces. Their delightfully naive view of life being that if they give something a 5* rating then it must be so. The problem is that prices have gone up to international 5* levels giving rise to the expectation that it will compare to other high graded hotels around the world. This maybe one of a group of Sri Lankan higher quality hotels but no way is it as 5* by INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS. At best it is a low 4*/high 3*. The entrance is spectacular and beautiful but the rest of the property is simply awful. Poor maintenance, unsafe tiles around the pools, under equipped rooms with intermittent electrical supplies and poor drainage. Hawkers on the beach screaming for your attention every time you go anywhere near them. Nobody walking around with any frequency to see if would like a drink whilst sunbathing etc. It could be so good if only they understood what makes a 5* hotel. Still delightful and enjoyable providing you don't go expecting the best, but it is poor value for money.

text: We were a group of 20 people in 10 rooms at Heritance Ahungulla for the new year. The service is absolutely the worst I have encountered across Asia. Staff in general are unhelpful and sometimes rude. The breakfast place is fine but the bar and snack place is absolutely terrible. We had to wait for almost an hour for a club sandwich and when asked three times they kept saying â€œ2 minutesâ€. Finally when I approached a more senior person at the bar, he was totally unapologetic and asked the same waiter who said â€œyeah, I will get itâ€. This is one example amongst many incidents - from no towels in the pool to poorly made up rooms. I certainly do not recommend it - there are many other places in Sri Lanka that are far better.

text: We stayed here between 18-24 June 2007 for part of our 3 centre honeymoon and we were amazed by both the country and the hotel. We were greeted by the Duty Manager and a refreshing cold towel and shown to our rooms following a brief introduction to the hotel as well as a choice of cocktail or wine upon ones arrival. One thing to bear in mind from the momnet you arrive in the hotel, is that tipping is a necessity, 100-200 rupees (50p-Â£1) is adequate and you will find that you tip practically everyone, so make sure you have small denominations of GBP or USD. We stayed in a standard room over looking the pool and the Indian Ocean. The room was exceptionally clean, with a well-stocked mini bar and a tv with various satellite channels. The room boasted a well equipped en-suite, with a huge walk-in shower. The balcony was big with a table and two chairs which were much used when watching the sun set! The room had wooden floors and tiles in the bathroom and there was seating area within the room with a sofa and table. The pool areas were very clean with plenty of sun loungers around. Once you found the sun lounger of your choice a member of staff would bring towels and an umbrella if so required to you. The jacuzzi was not operational all the time, though that is partly due to the lack of clientele, although when it was turned on, there were very few people using it anyway. Periodically, the waiters would bring round refreshing water melon free of charge which was always welcomed. Waiters were also there if you wanted a drink that would then be brought to your sunlounger. Be wary, if you do get a sun lounger facing the sea, you are likely to be bombarded with the locals trying to sell you their goods. A polite shake of the head will move them on as they cause no harm. The hotel have tried to move on the sellers, but they rely on tourism so basically bear with it or move nearer the pool. Although we were half board at this hotel, it was easy to eat in the coffee shop which was excellent value for money and they had a good range of foods. The breakfast were good, with a wide variety which catered for most nationalities, including Sri Lankans themselves who tend to have Pol Sambol (a type of curry) for their breakfast. The evening meal tends to be a buffet, but as the hotel was pretty empty, we had most of our meals from the A La Carte menu which was excellent. On the occasion we did have the buffet, there was a great choice of barbequed meats and freshly cooked meals, all of very high standards. Dress code is smart /casual. The hotel was only 1/3 full as a result of the lack of tourism following the Tsunami and the Civil War, which is such a shame as a lot of staff had to be laid off as a result. The Civil War is taking place to the far North East of Sri Lanka and it was only on the way back to the airport late at night did we ever see army personnel as there are many check points to go through, but don't let this put you off as it doesn't affect you at all. As a result of the low numbers, the evening entertainment was null and void, although as a honeymooning couple, this did not bother us as it was nice to have a walk around or a couple of drinks in the bar before retiring to the room. That being said, the hotel was busy over the weekend and the evening entertainment did pick up. There is nothing about the hotel we would change. The staff are friendly and extremely attentive and they will go out of their way to help you. The hotel in our opinion was worth every penny and would recommend it to anyone. PLEASE don't be put off with the post-Tsunami clear up as we hardly saw any of it taking place, although the hotel is a constant reminder how strong these people are in the face of adversity. The only evidence that you will see in the immediate vicinity of the resort is the boutique on the beach and you can see where the waves ripped the walls apart. Go to the Heritance Ahungalla, it is wonderful and we certainly go back and it is certainly worthy of its 4* reputation.

text: We had a great experience there. The staff and service was superb. The pool is open until 8pm. There was an indoor games area and library. I loved those places to spend the time. The rooms were clean and had a good bathroom. One of the best hotels in Sri lanka which provides great safety. but didn't have a nice view. If you are a sea food lover, you must visit this hotel. Crab, prawn, cuttlefish and many more seafood things in one place. Never experienced such a thing before. They had a good buffet with a lot of varieties and they served tasty foods. But only a few items were delicious. I experienced that drawback from this kind of bigger buffets serving hotels. Live music nights and a lot of services available through the hotel. I believe it was an amazing visit to Heritance Ahungalla.

text: We stayed 3 nights in a deluxe room - extremely comfortable and well appointed. Slept like a log every night. The staff could not have been more friendly and helpful at all times. The hotel itself was designed by renowned Sri Lankan architect Geoffrey Bawa, with great attention to detail - it is in a tropical style with lots of open space and courtyards/gardens within the hotel. Two huge swimming pools, and of course the beach (ocean swimming seasonal though). This is a great location for exploring the surrounding area - lots of other Bawa designed hotels and gardens to visit nearby, and of course the Unesco world heritage old town of Galle (Fort), which is a gem.

text: I returned to Heritance Ahungalla after several years to relive my memories from the last trip which was excellent. This time however the hotel fell way short in meeting my expectations. It all started with a 45 minute waiting time just to get checked in. The lobby was storming with guests and baggage scattered everywhere reminded me of a government hospital than a star class hotel. The room was very clean and neat however, I had booked myself in to a "Deluxe King" room with a "King Size" bed on the ground floor (printed on the confirmation). However I had been given a room on the 1st floor with two single beds put together. We were so eager to get to the beach that the minute we came to the room we unpacked and stormed off to the beach. It was when we returned we figured out that it was not a king size bed. Called and complained to the concierge and I was told that "Sir, you have to make a special request for a king size bed at the time of booking if you needed one". After 15 minutes of arguing and speaking to the duty manager was I offered to be shifted to another room. Again, a very clean and comfortable room but a small shower in a very odd triangular shape. Not for someone who is claustrophobic. We went for dinner in the main restaurant and it was chock-a-block. They had stuffed every available chair and table in to it and we could only move about sideways. The seemed to have a shortage of plates as we had to wait up to 5 minutes sometimes for fresh clean plates. And no service what so ever. There were only five or six waiting staff to serve and we hardly caught a glimpse of them. We were never even offered water. And I am still waiting for the tea I ordered to the table on the second morning of my visit. Dinner was really good. There was a very decent variety of food and the taste was very good. But breakfast was not so exciting. There was no variance and every day it was pretty much the same assortment. In-room dinning was an absolute disaster. It felt as if "In-room dinning" is a whole new concept that the hotel staff is yet to hear about. There was no menu available in the room and two cheaply printed A4 sheets stapled together arrived at the door 30 minutes when we called and asked for one. We ordered two fried rice and let me tell you that I have had better fried rice served on a plane. It was a mixture of rice and boiled chicken with the odd piece of carrot. The hotel is beautiful, comfortable and very clean. As long as you lower your exceptions in terms of service, you might have a decent stay. For me however, I do not see myself returning any time soon.

text: Our planned highlight, to the end of our Sri Lankan tour, was a frustrating disappointment. We arrived tired and sick, hoping for a clean comfortable room and some simple food. Even though we had booked and paid 6 months earlier, it took a long time to allocate us a room. The room smelled of mould and mould was easily found in the bathroom. My wife complained, but all the staff could do was find the missing outdoor furniture. At dinner, the first night, we had difficulty finding plain food, that would not aggravate our upset stomachs. The chef kindly offered to prepare mashed potatoes, peas and grilled chicken, for us, the next night. However, the next day, this offer was undone by management, who declared we had been selected for "Fine dining". Fearing this was Sringlish for extra spicy, we gave up and went to bed early, without dinned, which we had already paid for. At least at checkout, as some compensation, the hotel did not charge for the sandwich and hamburger, we had at the bar. After my wife presented mouldy toiletries to management, they did offer to change rooms, on the second day; but it was too little too late. The hotel has an impressive entrance and sea view. But what good are those when the hotel fails the basics of room and food.

text: I stayed here for 3 nights with my husband, my one year old and my four year old in August. This is a lovely hotel, well maintained with great staff. Everyone was very helpful and considerate especially as I spent most of my time running after my one year old. The only let down for us was that there wasnt a kids pool - my son could only stand up on the steps of the pool which meant we were constantly on guard. The close proximity of the beach was beautiful so the kids enjoyed the playing in the sand. The buffet was good - there was a different choice every night. For lunch we ate at the pool bar which i enjoyed more. There is a very small kids club room so the kids spent a little time colouring. I would recommend this hotel for older families or couple - purely based on the pool depth.

text: I recently visited Heritance with a group of friends after my wedding in Sri Lanka. We stayed there for 3 nights. The hotel itself was comfortable, with all the necessary amenities. The highlight was definitely the pool, which was great as the monsoon meant swimming in the beach wasn't possible. Another highlight was the quality of food at the dinner buffet which had great variety. The hotel has been there for a number of years and it turns out Aitken Spence (the company which owns the hotel) is opening another large hotel just down the road in the coming months. This may explain the "tired" state of Heritance as it seems like there hasn't been a lot of recent investments. Another disappointment was the lack of evening entertainment. Because Ahungalla itself is secluded with very little night life or day time options (compared to Hikkaduwa or Bentota) it was a shame that the night time activities were so limited. The only options we found were a tired lounge bar, and quiet pool side bar. When I compare it to other hotels in Bentota which had more live music and more bars it was disappointing.

text: An awful lot of the people complaining about this hotel are moaning that it 'isn't five star'. As I recall, until fairly recently, a hotel in the UK had to have a Corby Trouser Press in the room to gain that vital fifth star. So maybe people are taking their view of '5 star' from the UK and, if they are then they are probably right - it isn't UK 5 star. But if it was you'd be paying a hell of a lot more than Â£150/night for it. It is, by any measure a stunning hotel. Cleverly designed by Geoffrey Bawa this low rise hotel (ground floor and two floors above) is laid out to create a series of separate spaces that never seem crowded (they only have just over 100 rooms). The setting, right on the beach, is terrific and the two giant pools are a delight. Those people giving it a poor review also complain that it is 'tired'. It would hardly be surprising given the fight against the elements that must be waged to maintain it but I can't agree. The grounds are imaculate and, yes some of the corridors are showing their age but the spacious rooms are absolutely fine. I've also found the staff to be gracious, charming and attentive. Most Sri Lankans are but here they definitely go the extra kilometre. And you can't fault the food, especially the buffet breakfast which will set you up for the entire day. The buffet supper is also excellent with a cornucopia of choice and a good selection of wines. Don't believe the nay sayers, there's nothing wrong with this hotel.

text: We have just returned from our first trip to Sri Lanka. We had a wonderful time and Sri Lanka is stunning. We stayed at the Heritance Ahungalla expecting a little bit more than we got however the biggiest disappointment was how dirty and aged the rooms were. There was no bath and the shower was filthy as was the rest of the room. My son on the first night was sick (not sure how) however we asked that the room be fully cleaned the next day which is was not. You could still see the smears of sick on the floor from where we had cleaned during the night. The bed sheets were also stained and did make you wonder if the sheets were clean stains or not. The corridors to the rooms were also in a poor condition and looked more like the corridors on a run down housing estate (I can say that as I lived on one for 5 years). The bathroom amenities are also just refills with dirty lids so make sure you bring your own! However!! The staff were amazing and so attentive and the natural beauty of Sri Lanka makes it all worth while. Would we go back to the same hotel? No! Would we go back to Sri Lanka? Yes! Yes Yes! Special mention to Sri Lankian immigration too who are so friendly. Looking forward to returning to Sri Lanka.

text: Recently returned from a two week visit to Sri Lanka, staying mostly at the Heritance Ahungalla. The welcome was warm and friendly, with bags taken to the room quickly and efficiently. The room itself was clean, well decorated, cool and well equipped. We had a family suite, which had a bed big enough for an entire family!! Even though we had an additional single bed in the room, myself and my children shared the comfortable large bed and were very happy for the two weeks. The pools and poolside were cleaned daily. Sunbeds were easily acquired. We were in a group of 17 and found beds together every day we stayed around the pool. The quieter pool was slower for drinks, but ever so relaxing. The beach was breathtakingly beautiful. We weren't hassled at all. The current and waves were very strong during our stay, which meant swimming wasn't advised, however, we jumped and played in the waves which was lots of fun. All of the communal areas were kept clean and tidy. The lunch time menu at the bar was lovely. The chips and burgers were extremely yummy! Having booked on an all inclusive package, we used the one restaurant that was included for breakfast, occasional lunch and dinner every day. By the end of the first week, admittedly, this was a little monotonous. The food didn't vary very much from night to night, even though the chef did try to make it themed. However, the food was delicious and to a very high standard. It would have been nice to have a little more variety on offer though - perhaps in the way of a second restaurant/place to eat. Service for drinks in the restaurant was sporadic. Depending on the waiter, we could wait for around 15-20 minutes for drinks alone. We combatted this by building a rapport with one waiter, who after a few days, looked after us and would bring drinks quickly. The evening entertainment wasn't fantastic. And we found the evening's could drag a little. So be sure to take your own entertainment with you! While staying here, we attended a friends wedding. The wedding planner was very friendly, but failed to explain the traditions that the couple were undergoing in their service, which left them and the group confused. The hair and make up provided by the hotel were sufficient - although our bride did end up taking off the make up, as it was a little too much. The photographer was unobtrusive, yet quite dated in his approach. Even though these may sound quite negative, we couldn't fault the wedding itself, which was incredibly special to the couple and us as guests. The staff were so kind and helpful throughout. Overall, we were so pleased with our stay at the Heritance. All of the staff were happy and helpful. Everything was completed to a high standard. And yes, there were some aspects that could have made it even better, but overall, it's been a holiday of a lifetime. Would highly recommend a visit here!

text: We stayed at this place for 4 days 3 nights - US$1,100, included a lame New Year buffet and "celebration" (US$125 per person) This hotel bore no resemblance with its sister hotel in the same group Heritance Kandalama (where we stayed over Christmas and which was impressive). The architectual and design elememts that make Heritance Kandalama very special are total lacking in the Heritance Alungalla. The level of service could not compared. The attitude of staff generally was insincere and gear towards tips rather than service. We also had 2 experiences of male staff members making inappropriate comments to the females in our group. The food was uninspiring at best and unhygenically prepared at worst (one of our party and a known other guest were both made ill by poor food preparation.) When the issue was raised on our departure with the most senior staff member made available (only a room division manager), no responsiblity was taken nor apology offered and the stock response was that the guest had not until then made a formal complaint (despite the matter being known to reception and housekeeping staff) and the guest was blamed for not having asked for a hotel doctor at the time. The room we had was an attempt maximizing a corner area and was at first glance impressive. However, not all the electrics were wired up and the basic layout of the location of the light switches was poor (you have to get out of bed to turn off the bed side light). And one of the toilet in the suite smelt which affected our enjoyment of the suite. We couldn't use the sitting area of the suite. To cap it all, having paid US$100 for a vehicle to take us to the airport, the hotel provided a desperately underpower, mini people mover which had no safety belts for passengers (an essential requirement for Sri Lankan roads). Compared to the rest of our experience of accommodation in Sri Lanka, Heritance Alungalla was over-priced and poor value. It is definitely not 5 star accommodation as it claims to be. It just seems to be a money making "machine". The main positive point about this hotel is the beach which is beautiful like the rest of the West coast of Sri Lanka (you do have to however put up with beach touts). We will be lodging a formal complaint to the hotel but given their initial response we do not expect any joy.

text: As mentioned above the hotels seems to have changed its profile. The first thing that meets you after the majestic entry, that took my breath away the first time I came, is a large Russian banner. The hotel seems to accommodate huge groups of tourists from this country and many of them behave badly, bringing glass bottles into the pool, (drinking a lot in general) ignoring the personnel, treating the personnel like lesser beings (we saw this several times) and not greeting, making eye contact, or even acknowledging fellow hotel guests. I can understand that the world situation makes this awkward for them, but if you choose to travel out, you should make the effort- not expect to take over a beautiful tropical destination and ignore and cancel all others just by outnumbering them. I will not return to Heritance Ahungalla (the Triton to me) until this has changed. It was very expensive too, which is such a shame when the experience is so negative. I can understand the need to make money, but ruining such a beautiful hotel and experience along the way can hardly be worth it in the long run . Iâ€™m sure the architect Geoffrey Bawa wouldâ€™ve hated this development!

text: After coming from Heritance Kandalama we expected the same. This is not the case. I did not want to jump on here and be outright negative, but there is good and bad here. Our room has a broken aircon, bathroom exhaust fan, telephone and main door lock, with no safe. Pretty alarming. Our guy that cleans the room is wonderful and has tried his best to get everything fixed up. So far the kettle has been replaced. They have tried to fix the phone several times with no luck. Reception rings you constantly but you can not talk to them, very annoying. Outside the gates are pushy tuk tuk drivers in a dirty street. Surprising since Sri Lanka is a very clean country with mostly beautiful helpful people. Not here though. We were really looking forward to a few days in the pool looking at the ocean after a pretty hectic schedule. As soon as you get to the pool the yelling people on the beach trying to sell dodgy wares ruins it straight away. Even security and staff were called several times to try and help ripped off tourists. But security does nothing. It is like they work with them. After all the places we have stayed in Sri Lanka this is the worst. We would not come back here again.

text: On our way from Colombo to Galle we stopped by this establishment without prior reservation. The grand driveway and facade of the Heritance Hotel where impressive at first sight. Having arrived there the good impression faded quickly. The room rate given at the reception was US-Dollar 140 per room without breakfast, which is expensive for the island, but we accepted without a written receipt. First of all we had to wait over 1 hour to get the room. By that time the dinner was about to finish, so we were advised to go to the restaurant where a buffet was presented. The quality of the dishes were far from higher standards. The room was alright, but nothing special. The hotel was crowded with tourist groups from China. The next morning by the tome of check-out a bill was presented of 280 US-Dollar. The chef concierge refused to get the man on duty from yesterday night. The outrageous room rate was ompared by us with rates shown on booking sites. The same night rooms had been available from 58 US-Dollar! After were rude discussions we left the hotel with a "discount" of 60 US-Dollar and paid incredible 220 US-Dollar. A never come back experience!

text: What an experience itâ€™s been at this hotel. I canâ€™t rate it highly enough. We stayed here for six days in January and it was absolutely perfect from start to finish and thatâ€™s all down to the staff. If we return to Sri Lanka and this hotel - it wonâ€™t be for the bricks and mortar (although itâ€™s great) it will be for the very special people who work here. A special shout out to our room guy Rukmal! Iâ€™ve stayed in plenty of hotels around the world but I canâ€™t remember any as being so attentive to detail as Rukmal is. Everyday he makes me smile with the way he has dressed the room with flowers, nice cushions and the towel art is another levelâ€¦ Heâ€™s such a warm, happy, hard working guy. Also want to give special mention to two guys have made our trip incredible. Lilanga and Nipun - they have catered for our every wish and whim. We set them a challenge of getting us some vintage champagne so we could celebrate something special and the scoured the whole of the island, rang every hotel and managed to find two bottles of vintage Dom Perignon for us before we left. They really have pulled out all the stops to make our stay so memorable. They made sure all our dining has been spectacular by setting up a gorgeous table on the beach, three nights consecutively. I canâ€™t heap enough praise on them enough. Iâ€™m so glad we got to know these guys, and that should be a little tip for other travellers. The hospitality industry has taken a battered since Covid and the staff work so hard by trying to make every guest feel exceptional. I always like to show my appreciation by learning everyoneâ€™s name, giving them my time, conversation and a few words of encouragement - it really does go along way and it will make your time here go from great to excellent. You can move mountains with guys like Rukmal, Lilanga and Nipun on your team. They are an absolute credit to the hotel and the Heritance brand should know what assets they have working for them. The hotel is beach fronted large and comfortable. Both pools is absolutely huge and so warm and welcoming. The food has been wonderful and the evenings we have spent on the beach, dining by the waves have been exceptional. But everything is down to the staff here. Worth 10 stars just for them!

text: For the layabout to do nothing, the fitness fanatic to be at peak, the gourmet to garner all the delights or the holiday maker in search of serenity, there is one place in Sri Lanka all rolled into one. That is the five-star Heritance at Ahungalla, where the blue ocean kisses the sand and the swimming pool stands between the airy reception area. This may sound like a leaf from a flyer or an advertisement. It is not. Thatâ€™s my experience during a week-long stay at the luxury resort. The absence of what seems an orchestrated hustle and bustle in some of the resorts, being left alone from the taunting touts on the beach and caring of the staff made all the difference. I fell in love with what I saw and what I enjoyed. The buffet meals for breakfast, lunch and dinner had a wide variety to choose from â€“ a cross section of the most popular Sri Lankan cuisine and a widespread selection of western and continental food. That is not to mention the fine dining restaurants. If you need to learn a little more, go beyond what the glossy magazines and flashy advertisements on websites say. I did that. The tins, bottles, corrugated boxes and other degradable items do not go waste. There is a team to sort them to be re-cycled. An award winning Chef, Dimuthi Kumarasinghe finds no space on the walls of his room or his tables to place any more awards including trophies. They are full. Ask him to give you what they call an â€œindigenous meal.â€ Itâ€™s a three course lunch or dinner with produce including catch of the sea within a radius of five kilometres from the hotel. I told Manager Refhan N. Razeen that I was pampered. â€œThat is our style,â€ he said. So, if you also want to be pampered in southern Sri Lanka, Heritance is the resort. Donâ€™t believe me. Have a go, try it.

text: We had a very relaxing and enjoyable vacation after spending 4 nights at this 5 star hotel in Ahungalle. We stayed in a luxury room and the rest of our group in 4 other luxury rooms which were all fabulous in their own unique way. All rooms were extremely spacious and we were upgraded to a suite which had a huge living room along with a separate master bedroom equipped with flat screen, DVD player and sound system, a huge bathroom with shower stall, elevated jaccuzzi tub, separate his/hers sinks and a huge wrap around patio with deck chairs. I'll post some pictures to illustrate but please note these were taken just before we left so naturally the room was a bit messy. The hotel has all the amenities for fun with 2 outdoor pools, tennis courts, badminton court and table tennis. The main outdoor pool by the lobby overlooks the ocean and is very picturesque. We particularly enjoyed the other pool which had the shade of a large tree and hence it was never too sunny for a swim. The food was good with seafood at every meal and breakfast was by far the best meal as well as one night with a Sri Lankan fare dinner. Jananjaya a waiter from the main restaurant went out of his way to please and provided the best service I've ever experienced in a buffet setting. Kaushal one of the housekeepers was also very attentive and made lovely animals for our son from towels. Even David P a trainee at the hotel went above and beyond to ensure we had a great stay. Overall from the time we arrived the service was impeccable and probably largely attributed to the very unassuming and nice general manager Upul Peiris who appears to be leading from the front and has clearly set a high bar for the service culture, he mentioned he had previously managed several resorts in the Maldives. The only downside to this hotel is it was designed by a famous Sri Lankan architect who believes in blending in with nature and hence it is not safe for young kids to wonder around alone since the stairways do not have rails, there are ponds all over etc. There is also no separate kids swimming pool. The beach by the hotel is very nice, however, the ocean maybe a little too rough if waves and body surfing are not your thing.

text: Just returned from an 11 night stay at Heritance Ahungalla and already making plans to return. Check in was fast and faultless. The room was well appointed, spotless and, considering the amount of guests, quiet too. Efficiently cleaned daily (even the balcony), tea/coffee replaced, evening turn down service, couldn't fault it. Having spent a month travelling,in Sri Lanka, this was by far the best hotel of my trip. Breakfast buffet was something to look forward too with a superb and varied choice. The evening meals had a different theme with a massive array of western and asian dishes, all cooked and presented at a high standard. After a longish stay at a hotel, buffet meals can sometimes become a bit tedious with a longing to eat elsewhere, but despite several beach cafe choices, we were never tempted away from the quality food served at the hotel. Getting tea and coffee could require a bit of patience in the mornings but this is not logged as a complaint just a niggle when you need your early morning caffiene fix. The pools are amongst the best I saw in Sri Lanka, cleaned daily, the grounds kept neat and tidy and the beach vendors kept at bay by security and a respected boundry line although they do become a complete nusiance shouting and calling out to try and sell their goods but after a couple of days they tend to get the hang of who is worth pursuing and who needs to keep having sales tactics applied to. Beach is a beautiful mile plus of fine sand backed by palm trees and suprisingly free of plastic debris; not totally free but judged against standards of some asian beaches and the collection of bags etc that gets washed up, it's a gem. Only problem is that a walk along this beach is punctuated by the attention of several 'best friends' you never knew you had that want to get you to a cafe/gem shop/ tour but a firm 'no thanks' seems to be respected. There is a handy wine shop to the right of the hotel and several little shops that sell most stuff you could need but don't let any of the men that pounce on you the moment you walk through the gate follow you or continue any sort of converstion as they will be clocking a commission at your expense for taking you to the shop. They get the plan and politely telling them to stop, stay here and don't follow me is respected and didn't cause offence. Would I return to this hotel, too right I will. Would I recommend it, absolutely without hesitation!

text: Overall, the facilities were nice but we found this property to be poorly managed. 1) Check-in process wasn't organized well. 2 days after check-in, I was contacted and told I had an extra person and I had to pay more money. They didn't even bother understanding their error! We had provided all passports at check-in and we had booked 3 rooms. They had mixed up the adults/kids in the rooms and thought we tried to sneak in an adult at a kid rate. How is that possible if we provided our passports at check-in??? Then at check-out I was still charged and had to get it resolved again. 2) Food was average. And the setup is not optimal. Buffet is split into 2 rooms, with one room having large, open doors which basically let's in bugs/flies. This comes across as unhygienic and dirty. 3) When sitting out by the pool, had to ask 3 times to get towels and ended up getting them ourselves. 4) The room setup isn't good. The bathroom has blinds so it makes it really awkward for someone to use the bathroom. Also, the thermostat directions are on the balcony door (why not next to the thermostat). 5) We arrived on a Wednesday and were excited there would be a show. The show was terrible with what appeared to be some sort of mime type of performance. 6) The gym is a joke! You don't even feel like working out. It's small & cramped with old equipment. 7) There is one elevator that is old and slow.

text: As a well travelled guest, Heritance Ahungalla was one of the worst hotels I have been to. My friends and I arrived at the hotel after a long day, expecting the welcome they advertise. But we were greeted with nothing and yet I noticed the foreign tour group next to us at the hotel were getting a great welcome. The foreign guests were given a welcome drink in front of me and even when j was checking in, nothing was really done. This was extremely disappointing to see as their attention was on the foreign guests, even though the hotels are kept afloat by locals even in times of crisis. In a sense, it felt as if I and my friends were purposefully ignored at the welcome to focus on white people. Next, the rooms were OK and clean with the needed amenities. The pool was ok and the environment was relaxing and calm. But the Jacuzzis are broken and one was unusable. This really dampened the experience. Thirdly, the buffet. The food experience was TERRIBLE. I stayed ful board for 2 days and the food was the same everytime. There was not much variety and so, it was really disappointing. At one point during lunch, I found MOLD in my food!!! The same night during dinner, my friends and I ate carved roast pork and the meat was rotten. It smelled bad and when I ate a bite, it was so rotten and I had to throw it away. The breakfast buffet had some diversity and was enjoyable. The staff is nice and accommodates our wish. The bar makes a really good cocktail called the green pool. Other than that, it was a poor experience. Serving bad food to guests and ignoring local guests to focus only on foreign guests was what made me write this review. I never badly review anyplace I travel to unless its horrible, like ahungalla was. It did not serve a purpose to my business trip either. Would never visit again.

text: When we i read the inital review for this hotel i read all about eh room that smelt of mold. Well imagine my amusement(not ) after God knows how many hours of travel we arrive....hotel looks lovely...we check in...all good. We get showed to our room - we get showed around and then everyone stands still as the expected tip needs to be handed over. Fine, not great but fine. I then start having an asthma attack, due to the strong smell of mold. Yep I've got the moldy room!!!! We ask to get moved, which was quick and efficient, but i was really annoyed when another tip was expected. At this point i have to say that ws one of my main annoyances about Sri Lanka. of course when you travel to a less fortunate country you expect to tip, but i got out hand. Anyway, hotel was ok...room was nice, good size, bathroom great...Again slight annoyance, they cleaned everyday, but i didn't always think it was that thorough-. The food was fabulous, although we never had the buffet dinner,we ate mainly (when at the hotel) at the 24 h place. the top resturant wasn't open as the hotel wasn't busy enough.Brekafast were wide ranging and very tasty no complaints here. Great gym. which no one uses and it has a fabulous views out to sea- it felt like my own personal gym. The views are great , and the beach is wonderful, never crowded . Once you've told the beach touts that you'll buy something they're pretty good and leave you alone. I'm not sure when they're adding it, but there is no Spa on site, somoen comes in to do massage. I went down the road Eden Hotel & Spa, which i would definitely recommend. Spa is lovely-and they have great food aswell if you want to go for dinner. On the whole the Heritage was lovely, did the job, just a few annoyance, but mainly good.

text: WORST HOTEL EXPERIENCE. EVER.
cleaned_text: worst hotel experience ever

text: Having spent 8 days braving the roads of Sri Lanka touring their cultural triangle, we arrived at this hotel looking forward to a lovely rest for 7 days and we were not disappointed. This hotel is right on the beach and there is very little around it. It is for this reason that we went half board. A good decision is some respects as there is only one other bar 500 Metres up the beach along with a beach shack. The food at the beach bar was fine and considerably cheaper than the hotel should you be buying on a day to day basis. We often walked to the beach shack at a lunchtime for a beer (300 rupees and considerably larger than that offered by the hotel for 600R). The hotel, in effect has three restaurants. The buffet, the fine dining and the fish restaurant. If you are all inclusive or Â½ board you can use the buffet (drinks are extra) but if you choose to use the other two you have to pay. We did not use the fine dining but the food looked good. We did use the fish restaurant on my birthday and it was a pleasant change to the buffet. The surrounding are not particularly appealing, the table and stools not comfortable. Because it was my birthday they had prepared a lovely table for me and provided â€˜properâ€™ chairs making for a much more comfortable experience. The fish was fresh and delicious and went well with the white wine we had ordered. Because Sri Lanka does not produce wine, it is imported and so by locals standards, quite expensive, but no more so that what we pay in the UK. I do feel that the hotel could offer a discount at these two restaurants if you had paid for Â½ board or all inclusive but chose not to use the buffet The buffet has a large selection of food on offer and so if you were just using the one hotel for your stay in this country a great way to try the curries that seem to make up the staple diet. (You can even have curry for breakfast). There was considerably more than curry though raging from salads (all cleaned in bottled water), soups to fish and meats. The range of sweets was very good and finished the meal off nicely. My criticism is that perhaps there is too much choice with the main course and as a consequence the food was on the whole not that hot and it was definitely quantity over quality. I cannot say the food was bad, but in my experience it was no more than average. I have certainly eaten a lot better around the world. Breakfast was once again a buffet with a very good selection or hot food and pastries and continental. In my opinion a better experience than the dinner. Turning to the rooms. We were first given a room on the second floor (they use the American system so no ground floor (1)) with a sea view. Number 229. Ok there were some trees in the way so perhaps sea glimpses would be more appropriate, but that did not distract from the fact that we could see and hear it. The room was not that far from the reception but we were told it was a quiet room. It was very â€˜tiredâ€™ with the decor needing to be updated. At around 9pm we could hear the singer in the bar and also people arriving in reception. The music went onto 11:00 by which time i had been to reception to arrange to move. This was the only major complaint I have as the man on the desk first told me the hotel was full and then looked at his watch as if it was relatively early and made me feel that it was my fault that at 10pm I wanted to get to bed. After not accepting the excuse that it was full they arranged for us to move further along the corridor to the far end of the hotel, well away from the bar and reception the following day. This was in the same design room but one that had been decorated and refurbished. This had been done to a high standard and was very comfortable. We had this for free but they do charge $20 a night for the privilege of having a room that has been refurbished. We were told that the original rooms had not been decorated in 32 years. The room was cleaned daily sheets and towels changed. In the evening housekeeping came round to see if everything is ok and if you needed anything. I think at this point I need to say that all the staff were always friendly, polite and willing to help. Nothing seemed too much effort for them. I cannot praise the staff enough and they certainly make your stay enjoyable. There are two pools, the infinity pool that you see as you arrive at reception, and another in the grounds that whilst not infinity is big enough to swim/cool off and is far less crowded, by far the better choice in my opinion. There are more than enough sun beds, but as at most resorts there are some that insist on putting their towels on the beds that they consider their own for the duration of their stay. If you are prepared to tip the pool attendants, as some did, they will put towels on the beds for you, as they set them up early in the morning If you have a bed by the perimeter you do get hawkers that are in the grounds of the hotel, but stay on the perimeter trying to sell you trousers and sarongs (my wife bought two pairs of trousers at a shop on our travels for 500R whilst the hawkers wanted 2000R for one pair!) I am told that the hotel intend to keep them out of the grounds in the near future. I am aware that this seems a bit negative, not something that I intended as i wanted to give constructive criticism and to make it informative for those considering booking this hotel. I would have no hesitation in booking this hotel. The new rooms are lovely, the ground beautiful (watch out for the little tree squirrels and the small Iguanas) that are lovely to see. Of course in conclusion I reiterate that staff is amongst the best I have encountered and make this hotel what it is.

text: Just came back from two weeks in HA. This is a lovely hotel and we cannot add too much to the previous positive reviews but just would like to share some of the points that we think worth to be mentioned. Location. This is the most important thing that needs to be considered if you plan to choose this hotel. The thing is that it is unexpectedly isolated. Most of the beach side hotels in Sri Lanka (especially such big as HA) have a developed touristic infrastructure just outside their entrance doors - shops, travel agencies, restaurants, etc. HA is not the case. Here you can find only two restaurants on the beach and â€¦ thatâ€™s all. Needless to say that the prices for everything (from taxi to excursions) are the same or just a bit less than in the hotel. Just as an example we found out that ordering a room service dinner is cheaper than going to the restaurants. So, be prepared. At the same time the good point is that the Beach is just perfect. Because the hotel is so isolated the whole huge shore line is used only by the guests. This is the advantage that cannot be underestimated. Rooms Rooms are Ok. Not bad but nothing special. We were staying in the luxury room on the second floor. All floors have all types of rooms, but the third floor is considered â€˜specialâ€™ and costs some extra money. We asked for relocation to the third floor but were explained that we needed to pay a difference. As it was written in the other reviews only the third floor had a full sea view. The second and first have it only partial. This does not mean that the view is bad â€“ no, youâ€™ll be overlooking the big (really big) and nice (really nice) pool or picturesque garden with monkeys and varans . Position HA stands rather far away from the main touristic attractions of the central and southern Sri Lanka. If you want to see something you should expect to get up at 5 or 3 a.m. to spend a whole day in the car. The trip from the airport takes around 2.5-4 hours. When you negotiate with taxi it is advisable to make it clear from the very beginning that the price include highway fee. If you do not choose highway be ready to spend 4 hours in the permanent traffic jam on the local road. Conclusion Would I recommend this hotel? Yes, why not. It is well maintained, stylish and relaxing. If you like the beach relaxation, travel with a kid or just want to have a break after exploring the island HA might be a good option. Would I come back? No, next time weâ€™d rather choose some of the hotels on the south closer to Galle.

text: The hospitality starts from the 1st step into the hotel; warm welcome with traditional variety of fresh juices. Front desk was very helpful and friendly. Once they saw the kids, they were informing the parents about the events organized for the kids on that day. They had magic show and chef programs for kids during our stay. The room was clean. This hotel has 2 pools; The green pool with Jacuzzi and trees around is my choice and it is the best. They also have plenty of indoor and outdoor sports.

text: When you arrive at this hotel you cannot help but be impressed. There is a large water feature outside reception and a lovely pool just inside. The rooms were pleasant but not great. When I got to the balcony the sea view was not quite what I imagined, the hotel is set a bit further back than it may appear in brochure photos. Found the staff very pleasant and the buffet choices quite expansive. The major disappointment were the cocktails on offer on the all inclusive. A couple off the Arrack based ones were OK but the others were pretty naff. Other AI's I have been to have a better range, although sometimes there is a small charge for the more expensive ones. Here it is full payment for non AI menu.

text: Hotel ambiance itself was very relaxing. The check in process was taking bit of a time, but that was not much of a problem as we had time to lool around the property. I would say that the staff were not too open to help. They mostly replied with a negative sense. The buffet spread was amazing. They have a separate vegetarian corner that is easy to figure out. Nothing to be blamed of the taste.It was amazing. The main pool is a bit too opened to the lobby. The second pool is lovely. The highlight is the warm water jacuzzi that is there near the pool. The rooms were too clustered and badly need refurbishment. In one of the rooms we had the lock was broken. The water pressure in the shower was too much. Lastly I would say that the guests must have their freedom to review the hotel after their stay. I feel it is very wrong to force a review. May be they can suggest to leave a review on tripadvisor, but it is not required for the staff to download it on the guest's phone and wait till the review is posted. If this happens please get a moment off and tell them you will go back and post a review.
